a.  Clearing and grubbing. Clearing and grubbing of the required right-of-way shall be complete in accordance with specifications contained in section 201 of the South Carolina State Highway Department, Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, Edition of 1973. 
b.  Sub-grade. Sub-grade work shall be complete in accordance with specifications contained in section 208 of the South Carolina State Highway Department Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, Edition of 1973. 
c.  Roadway base and surfacing. Roadway base work and surfacing shall be carried out in accordance with the state highway department's Typical Sections for Earth Type Base, Course and Asphalt Surfacing for Horry County, and section 303: Earth Type Base Course, section 310. Hot Laid Sand Asphalt Base Course, and section 403: Hot Laid Asphalt Concrete Surface Course of the of the South Carolina State Highway Department, Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, Edition of 1973. 
d.  Shoulders and ditches. 
1.  All shoulders and slopes shall be prepared in compliance with section 209 of the South Carolina State Highway Department Standard Specifications for Highway Construction. Edition of 1973. 
2.  All shoulders and slopes shall be protected from erosion. 
(2)  Drainage. 
a.  Adequate storm drainage shall be provided throughout the subdivision by means of pipes or graded channels, and storm drain pipes shall be placed at all low points in the street grade to transmit stormwater transversely across the street at the low points. In no case shall stormwater be transmitted more than 500 feet in the gutter line. 
b.  The minimum size pipe shall be 15 inches, regardless of drainage area, and shall be laid on a grade of not less than two-tenths percent. The minimum cover for all pipe shall be two feet. Ditches should be a minimum of two feet in width. The planning commission shall, for each proposed subdivision, establish minimum depth of ditches upon recommendations by the city engineer. 
c.  All surface drainage pipe shall be concrete pipe of a class conforming to State Highway Department Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, section 90, Edition of 1964. For special conditions, pipe recommended by the manufacturer for the type installation involved, and approved by the city engineer, will be considered. Any pipe laid between the concrete curbs shall be reinforced. No other type pipe will be considered. All pipe shall be laid with the bell or grove up grade and joint entirely interlocking. 
(3)  Public open spaces. Where a school, neighborhood park or recreation area, or public access to water frontage, shown on an official map or a plan made and adopted by the planning commission, is located in whole or in part in the applicant's subdivision, the planning and zoning commission may require the reservation of these open spaces within the subdivision up to a total of five percent of the gross area or water frontage of the plot, for park, school, or recreational purposes for a period not to exceed three years. 
(4)  Water and sewer facilities. Water and sewer facilities shall be provided in accordance with the standard procedures and policies of the city and the state board of health and shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(5)  Sidewalks. The planning commission may require the subdivider to construct sidewalks within the right-of-way of public streets to connect with existing or proposed sidewalks and along major thoroughfares and collector streets where sidewalks are needed for pedestrian traffic, such as to school and recreational areas. Sidewalks where constructed, shall be done so in accord with section 721 of the of the South Carolina State Highway Department. Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, Edition of 1973. 
(Code 1980, § 5-3-32; Ord. No. 990427-20, 4-27-99) 
Sec. 20-63. - Financial guarantees. 
(a)  General. Financial guarantees covering all improvements required by this article shall be prerequisite to planning commission action on the application for final plat approval. The subdivider shall submit such guarantees to the commission and the city council in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(b)  Certification of construction. In subdivisions where the subdivider completes the construction and installation of all required improvements, the subdivider shall file with the planning commission written certification by the building inspector that such improvements have been completed according to the final plat and design drawings and specifications submitted therewith, and according to the requirements of this article, and that such improvements have been accepted by the city or appropriate governmental unit for maintenance. 
(c)  Performance bond. Prior to completion of any or all requirement improvements by the subdivider, the subdivider may post a performance bond with the city guaranteeing the completion of such improvements in compliance with the requirements in this article. 
(1)  The city shall have the right to refuse a performance bond for any and/or all required improvements and require construction and installation thereof by the subdivider. 
(2)  Where accepted by the city, the performance bond shall: 
a.  Run to the city, or if applicable, any other governmental unit having a legal responsibility for the construction and completion of such improvements. 
b.  Be in an amount equal to 125 percent of the costs as estimated by the city of any improvements which have not been constructed, installed, and completed in compliance with the requirements of this article prior to the posting of the bond and for which sufficient certification has been furnished in compliance with subsection (b) of this section. 
c.  Be with surety as approved by the city. 
d.  Specify that all the required improvements shall be completed in accordance with the requirements of this article within a period not to exceed one year from the date of posting the bond; provided, however, that the city may, by proper application, for good cause shown, extend the time of completion of all or a part of such improvements for such period of time as it deems is in the public interest. 
e.  Run until and terminate 90 days after filing of certificate of completion and acceptance as required in subsection (b) of this section, unless the planning commission or city determines that the requirements, standards and specifications of this article applicable to the construction, installation, and completion of the improvements have not been met and notifies the applicant of such determination by certified mail, in which event the bond shall continue to run until the filing of acceptable proof that the standards, requirements, and specifications have been met. 
(3)  If any or all of the required improvements are not completed within the time specified in the bond, the city may let or re-let the contract, and the subdivider and performance bond shall be severally and jointly liable for the costs thereof to the amount specified for such improvements in the bond. 
(d)  Prepayment. In lieu of construction by the subdivider of any or all required improvements, the subdivider may make payment to the city of the full amount of the improvements in compliance with the requirements in this section. 
(1)  The city shall have the right to refuse prepayment for any and/or all required improvements and require construction and installation thereof by the subdivider. 
(2)  Where accepted by the city, prepayment shall be in an amount equal to 125 percent of the cost as established by the governing authority of the required improvements which have not been either completed and certified and accepted as provided in subsection (b) of this section or covered by a performance bond as provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(3)  Where payment is accepted by the city, the construction and installation of all improvements covered thereby shall be performed by the city. After completion of said improvements, any unexpended amounts shall be refunded the subdivider by the city. 
(e)  Bond funds. Any funds received from the financial guarantees required by this article shall be used only for the purpose of making the improvements for which the guarantees were provided. 
(Code 1980, § 5-3-33; Ord. No. 990427-20, 4-27-99) 
Sec. 20-64. - Appeal. 
    An appeal from the decision of the planning commission must be taken to the circuit court within 30 days after actual notice of the decision, pursuant to Section 6-29-1150 of the state code of laws. 
(Ord. No. 2008-73, 9-23-08) 
Secs. 20-65-20-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VESTED PROPERTY RIGHTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005-39, §§ 7.1-7.7, 7.10, 7.11, adopted June 28, 2005, amended the Code by adding provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions have been included herein as §§ 20-71-20-79. 

Sec. 20-71. - Legislative findings. 
    As an incident to the adoption of this article, the city council, as the governing body of the city, makes the following findings: 
(1)  The South Carolina General Assembly has enacted the "Vested Rights Act", which is codified as S.C. Code Ann. § 6-29-1520 et seq., as amended, (the "Act"). 
(2)  The Act requires local governments to enact land development ordinances and regulations implementing the provisions of the Vested Rights Act on or before July 1, 2005. The Act authorizes local governments to establish a procedure for the vesting of rights in certain development plans, and provides that local governments that do not pass land development ordinances and/or ordinances implementing a procedure for the establishment of vested rights will be subject to the requirements of S.C. Code § 6-29-1560 of the Act, under which a landowner has a vested right to proceed in accordance with an approved site specific development plan upon the terms and conditions and subject to the requirements and limitations of S.C. Code Ann. § 6-29-1560(A), which section substitutes statutory conditions for vesting, thereby reducing local control and flexibility. 
(3)  Council finds that the Code of Laws of the City of Myrtle Beach, chapter 20, Subdivision Regulations should be amended by enacting article V to conform to the requirements of the Vested Rights Act; facilitate the administration of zoning and land use codes, ordinances and regulations; provide a fair and equitable process and procedure for the administration of county codes, ordinances and regulations; and promote the public health, safety, order, appearance, prosperity and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2005-39, § 7.1, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 20-72. - [Definitions.] 
    The following words and terms shall have the following meanings as used in this article: 
    Approved or approval means a final action by the governing body or an exhaustion of all administrative remedies from decisions of City of Myrtle Beach zoning, planning or land use officials, boards or commissions which results in the authorization of a site specific development plan or a phase of a phased development plan. 
    Building permit means a written warrant, license or permit issued by a local building official that authorizes the construction or renovation of a building or structure at a specific location. 
    Conditionally approved or conditional approval means an interim action taken by the city body that provides preliminary or conditional authorization for a site specific development plan or a phased-development plan which is subject to further approval. 
    Landowner means an owner of a legal or equitable interest in real property, including the heirs, devisees, successors, assigns and personal representatives of the owner. "Landowner" may include a person holding a valid option to purchase real property pursuant to a contract with the owner to act as his agent or representative for purposes of submitting a proposed site specific development plan or a phased development plan pursuant to this article. 
    Local governing body means the governing body of the City of Myrtle Beach or a city body authorized by statute or by the governing body of the City of Myrtle Beach to make land use decisions. Local governing body shall include the term "city". 
    Person means an individual, corporation, business or land trust, estate, trust, partnership, association, two or more persons having a joint or common interest, or any legal entity as defined by South Carolina Laws. 
    Phased development plan means a development plan submitted to the local governing body or body authorized by the local governing body to make land use decisions that shows the types and density or intensity of uses for a specific property or properties to be developed in phases, but which do not satisfy the requirements for a site specific development plan. 
    Real property or property means all real property that is subject to the land use and development ordinances or regulations enacted, approved or promulgated by the City of Myrtle Beach Council, and includes the earth, water and air above, below or on the surface, and includes improvements or structures customarily regarded as part of real property. 
    Site specific development plan means a development plan submitted to the local governing body or a body authorized by the local governing body to make land use decisions by a landowner describing with reasonable certainty the types and density or intensity of uses for a specific property or properties. The plan may be in the form of, but is not limited to, the following plans or approvals: planned development; subdivision plat; preliminary or general development plan; variance; conditional use or special use permit plan; conditional or special use district zoning plan; or other land use approval designations as are used by the City of Myrtle Beach; provided that all such plans must conform to, comply with and satisfy all applicable planning, zoning, subdivision, storm water management and control, building, fire, water and sewer, road and other City of Myrtle Beach codes and ordinances applicable to such development. 
    Vested right means the right to undertake and complete the development of property under the terms and conditions of a site specific development plan or an approved phase of a phased development plan as provided in this article, the Vested Rights Act and in the City of Myrtle Beach land development ordinances or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2005-39, § 7.2, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 20-73. - Establishment of vested right. 
(a)  A vested right as defined herein is established for two years, except for building permits, upon the approval of a site-specific development plan. 
(1)  If a developer creates only single family residential lots of five acres or less in size or an extension of public right-of-way is required, then a vested right to develop pursuant to a preliminary or final subdivision plat review attaches upon approval of the planning commission and the required public recordation of the plat. 
(2)  If a developer creates lots for any land use other than single family residential lots of five acres or less in size, then a vested right to develop pursuant to a preliminary or final subdivision plat review attaches only upon the final approval of the community appearance board or the planning commission, whichever has final review responsibility for App. A, section 903, and then only to the detail of the plan submitted. 
(3)  If a developer creates single family residential lots of five acres or more in size, a vested right to develop pursuant to a preliminary or final subdivision plat review attaches upon city staff approval and the required public recordation of the plat. 
(4)  A vested right to develop only a single-family residential unit on an existing lot of record attaches only upon the issuance of a building permit, provided however the vested right to act under a permit shall be six months as provided by the building code. 
(5)  A vested right to develop multi-use, mixed use, industrial use or commercial use property and single family residential on the oceanfront attaches only after the community appearance board has approved the plans for development. 
(6)  A vested right to develop a phased development plan attaches only upon community appearance board approval of the plans. 
(7)  A vested right to develop a planned unit development district attaches only upon approval of the plan by the community appearance board. 
(b)  The landowner of real property with a vested right may apply in writing before the end of the vesting period or within 30 days after the expiration of the vesting period or any extension thereof but not thereafter to the body for an annual one-year extension of the vested right. The body must approve applications for at least five annual extensions of the vested right if a timely and proper application has been filed with the body unless an amendment to land development ordinances or regulations has been adopted that prohibits approval. If no timely and properly written application is made by the landowner to the body for an annual extension, the vesting period or annual extension applicable to such real property shall expire at the end of the vesting period or the annual extension thereof. 
(c)  The city shall not provide for or approve the establishment of a two-year vested right in a conditionally approved site-specific development plan. No two-year vested right is established in a conditionally approved site-specific development plan until such vested right is specifically and expressly approved by the city in writing when a site-specific development plan is approved without conditions. 
(d)  The city shall not approve the establishment of a vested right in an approved phased development plan but may approve and establish a vested right in any phase of a phased development plan which conforms to, complies with and satisfies all state statutes and county codes and ordinances including, but not limited to, planning, zoning, subdivisions, storm water management and control, building, fire, water and sewer, road and other state and county codes applicable to such development. 
(e)  No vested right in a site specific development plan shall attach or be established until plan applications and required documents have been received, all required approvals have been given or granted, and all fees have been paid in accordance with the procedures outlined in this code. No vested right attaches or is established until a final decision has been rendered favorable to the applicant on all administrative appeals. 
(f)  The City of Myrtle Beach Zoning Board of Appeals is not authorized to grant or approve a vested right and no vested right shall be established, created or accrue as a result of any decision of the zoning board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 2005-39, § 7.3, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 20-74. - Conditions and limitations of vested right. 
(a)  A vested right established by this article and in accordance with the standards and procedures in the city zoning, land development and land use ordinances and regulations is subject to the following conditions and limitations: 
(1)  The form and content of a site specific development plan submitted by a landowner must conform and comply with the city planning, zoning, subdivision, storm water management and sediment control, building, electrical, mechanical, life safety, fire, water and sewer, road and other codes, ordinances and regulations applicable to such development or development plan. 
(2)  No vested right in a site specific development plan shall be established except in conformity with the city planning, zoning, subdivision, storm water management and sediment control, building, electrical, mechanical, life safety, fire, water and sewer, road and other land use codes, ordinances and regulations. 
(3)  If the city approves a vested right for one or more phases of a phased development plan, a site specific development plan shall be required for approval with respect to each phase in accordance with regulations in effect at the time of vesting; 
(4)  No vested right is established under a conditionally approved site-specific development plan or conditionally approved phased development plan. Any approved site specific development plan or approved phased development plan or phase thereof may be terminated by the city upon its determination, following notice and a public hearing, that the landowner has failed to meet the terms of the approval; 
(5)  A vested right established in accordance with the provisions of this article shall be vested upon approval by the city of the site specific development plan or specific phase of a phased development plan that authorizes the developer or landowner to proceed with investment in grading, installation of utilities, streets and other infrastructure and to undertake other specific expenditures necessary to prepare for application for a building permit. No developer or landowner shall proceed with investment in grading, installation of utilities, streets or other infrastructure, or shall undertake other significant expenditures necessary to prepare for application for a building permit before a site specific development plan or phased development plan or phase thereof authorizing such improvements and expenditures has been approved by the city. No investment in grading, installation of utilities, streets or other infrastructure, or other significant expenditures shall give rise to or establish a vested right until the city has approved the site specific development plan or phased development plan or phase thereof that authorizes the developer or landowner to proceed with improvements or undertake other significant expenditures on the real property which is proposed for development. 
(b)  A site specific development plan for which a variance, regulation or special exception is necessary, does not qualify and may not claim or receive vested right status unless and until the variance, regulation or special exception is obtained and the site specific development plan has been approved without conditions or exceptions. A phased development plan for which a variance, regulation or special exception is necessary does not qualify and may not obtain a vested right until the variance, regulation or special exception is obtained and the phase of the phased development plan has been approved without condition or exception. 
(c)  A vested right for a site specific development plan expires two years after vesting; provided, however, that the landowner of real property with a vested right may apply to the city before the end of the vesting period or within 30 days after the expiration of the vesting period or any extension thereof, but not thereafter, for an annual extension of the vested right for a period of one year. If a timely and proper written application is made, the city must approve applications for no more than five successive annual extensions unless an amendment to land development ordinances or regulations has been adopted that prohibits approval of such annual extension applications. The city shall designate the vesting point for a phased development plan as the date of approval of each phase of the phased development plan. The city may extend the time for a vested site specific development plan to a total of five years upon a determination that there is just cause for the extension and that the public interest is not adversely affected. Upon expiration of a vested right, a building permit may be issued for development only in accordance with applicable land development ordinances and regulations then applicable. 
(d)  A vested site specific development plan or a vested phased development plan which has been approved by the city may be amended if the amendments are approved by the city pursuant to the provisions of applicable city land development ordinances and regulations. 
(e)  A validly issued building permit does not expire or is not revoked upon expiration or termination of a vested right, except for public safety reasons or as prescribed by the applicable building code. 
(f)  A vested right to a site specific development plan or a phase of a phased development plan may be revoked by the city upon its determination, after notice and a public hearing, that there was a material misrepresentation by the landowner or substantial non-compliance with the terms and conditions of the original or amended approval. 
(g)  A vested site specific development plan or a vested phase of a phased development plan is subject to later enacted federal, state or local laws or ordinances adopted to protect public health, safety and welfare, including, but not limited to, building, fire, plumbing, electrical and mechanical codes and non-conforming structure and use regulations which do not provide for the grandfathering of the vested right. The issuance of a building permit vests the specific construction project authorized by the building permit to the building, fire, plumbing, electrical and mechanical codes in force at the time of the issuance of the building permit. 
(h)  A vested site specific development plan or vested phased development plan or phase thereof is subject to later local governmental overlay zoning that imposes site plan-related requirements but does not affect allowable types, height as it affects density or intensity of uses or density or intensity of uses. 
(i)  A change in the zoning district designation or land use regulations made subsequent to vesting that affects real property does not operate to affect, prevent or delay development of the real property under a vested site specific development plan or vested phase of a phased development plan without the consent of the landowner. 
(j)  If real property having a vested site specific development plan or vested phased development plan or phase thereof is annexed, the governing body of the municipality to which the real property has been annexed must determine, after notice and public hearing in which the landowner is allowed to present evidence, if the vested right is effective after the annexation. 
(k)  The city must not require a landowner to waive his vested rights as a condition of approval or conditional approval of a site specific development plan or phased development plan or phase thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2005-39, § 7.4, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 20-75. - Nature of vested right. 
    A vested right pursuant to this article or the Vested Rights Act is not a personal right but attaches to and runs with the applicable real property. The landowner and all successors to the landowner who secure a vested right pursuant to the Vested Rights Act or this article may rely upon and exercise the vested right for its duration, subject, however, to applicable federal, state and local laws adopted to protect public health, safety and welfare, including, but not limited to, building, fire, plumbing, electrical and mechanical codes and non-conforming structure and use regulations which do not provide for grandfathering of the vested right. Nothing contained herein shall preclude judicial determination that a vested right exists or does not exist pursuant to other statutory provisions. 
(Ord. No. 2005-39, § 7.5, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 20-76. - Landowner rights deemed vested. 
(a)  The landowner's rights are considered vested in the types of land use and density or intensity of uses defined in the development plan, and the vesting is not affected by later amendments to a zoning ordinance or land use or development regulation if the landowner: 
(1)  Obtains or is the beneficiary of a significant affirmative government act that remains in effect allowing development of a specific project; 
(2)  Relies in good faith on the significant affirmative government act; and 
(3)  Incurs significant obligations and expenses in the diligent pursuit of the specific project in reliance on the significant affirmative government act. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the following are significant affirmative governmental acts allowing development of a specific project: 
(1)  The local governing body has accepted exactions or issued conditions that specify a use related to a zoning amendment; 
(2)  The local governing body has approved an application for a rezoning for a specific use; 
(3)  The local governing body has approved an application for a density or intensity of use; 
(4)  The local governing body has granted a special exception or use permit with conditions; 
(5)  The local governing body has approved a variance; 
(6)  The local governing body or its designated agent has approved a preliminary subdivision plat, site plan or plan of phased development for the landowners property and the applicant diligently pursued approval of the final plat or plan within a reasonable period of time under the circumstances; or 
(7)  The local governing body or its designated agent has approved a final subdivision plat, site plan or plan of phased development or phase thereof for the landowner's property. 
(Ord. No. 2005-39, § 7.6, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 20-77. - Educational requirements for planning and zoning officials. 
    Appointed officials and professional employees must comply with additional educational requirements of S.C. Code § 6-29-1320(B) as amended by Act 39 of 2003 on or before January 1, 2006. 
(Ord. No. 2005-39, § 7.7, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 20-78. - Severability and repeal of inconsistent provisions. 
    The provisions of this article are hereby declared to be severable, and if any provision or section of this article is declared to be unconstitutional or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, such declaration shall not affect the constitutionality, legality or enforceability of any other section or provision of this article. Any provision of law inconsistent with the time of vesting of development rights as set forth herein is hereby repealed to the only the degree of inconsistency. 
(Ord. No. 2005-39, § 7.10, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 20-79. - Effective date. 
    This article shall become effective immediately upon its adoption. 
(Ord. No. 2005-39, § 7.11, 6-28-05) 
Chapter 20.5 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 98-31, §§ 1-18, adopted June 23, 1998, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion as §§ 20.5-1-20.5-18 is at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 20.5-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as "The City of Myrtle Beach Telecommunications Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 1, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-2. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings set out: 
    Applicant means a telecommunications provider that applies for consent or a franchise pursuant to this chapter. An applicant shall have applied for all regulatory authority required pursuant to subsection 20.5-4(c) hereof. 
    Consent agreement means an agreement that authorizes a telecommunications provider that does not serve customers within the city to construct and operate transmission lines using city streets. 
    Franchise means, for the purposes of this chapter, a special privilege granted by the city pursuant to state law to permit the use of city rights-of-way by a person for the purpose of installing, maintaining, repairing or operating telecommunications facilities. 
    Franchise fee means compensation paid to the city by the telecommunications provider in exchange for the use of the city's streets. For the purposes of this chapter this term includes a fee paid pursuant to a consent agreement. 
    Gross revenues means all revenue regardless of the source, received directly or indirectly, including in-kind services or goods, by a telecommunications provider from or in connection with the retail delivery of telecommunications services in the city, provided, however, that "gross revenues" shall not include any taxes on services which are imposed directly on any customer of a telecommunications provider by the United States, the State of South Carolina, the city, the school board, or any other governmental unit and which are collected on behalf of such governmental unit. "Gross revenues" does not include wholesale revenues derived from the sale or lease of capacity, bundled or unbundled elements of a telecommunications system, or telecommunications services to a telecommunications provider. 
    Person means any individual, resident, citizen, business, firm, corporation, partnership, governmental agency, other business entity, or institution. 
    Streets means all streets, roads, highways, alleys, rights-of-way, utility easements, public property, public ways and air space over such streets, roads, highways, alleys, rights-of-way, utility easements, public property and public ways located within the geographic limits of the city. 
    Telecommunications means the transmission, between or among points specified by the user, of information of the user's choosing (e.g., data, video and voice), without change in the form or content of the information sent and received. 
    Telecommunications facilities or facilities means all conduits, manholes, poles, antennas, transceivers, wires, cable (including fiber optic cable) and appurtenances owned or utilized by a telecommunications provider and located in, under or over the streets, utility easements, public property, and public ways of the city and utilized in the provision of telecommunications services, including digital or analog, voice, data, and video imaging and any other telecommunications services. 
    Telecommunications provider or provider means any person, including its affiliates and subsidiaries, other than the city, that provides, or is applying to provide, telecommunications services within the geographic boundaries of the city by utilizing its own telecommunications facilities to provide telecommunications services. A person that has transmission lines within, upon, over or under city streets, whether or not that person provides services within the city, is included within this definition for the purposes of this chapter. 
    Telecommunications services or services means any activity for delivering telecommunications by a telecommunications provider within the geographic boundaries of the city that the provider is authorized to provide under federal, state and local law, except that these terms do not include "cable service" as defined in the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, 47 U.S.C. § 521 et seq., and the Telecommunications Act of 1996. 
    Transmission line means a telecommunications facility that is used solely for the purpose of transmitting signals from one point outside the city to another point outside the city and does not include a line for the purpose of delivering telecommunications services to any person in the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 2, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-3. - Requirement of city's consent. 
(a)  Every telecommunications provider that utilizes a telecommunications facility to provide services within the city must first obtain a city business license. Every telecommunications provider must also obtain consent or a franchise from the city in accordance with this chapter in order to construct, maintain, or operate any facilities within, on, over or under any city street. Prior to providing any telecommunications service or constructing or utilizing any telecommunications facility, the provider must provide a written acceptance of the terms and conditions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 3, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-4. - Application process. 
(a)  Any telecommunications provider seeking to provide telecommunications service or utilize city streets (the "applicant") shall complete a brief application form approved by the department of public works. Such application form shall briefly describe the general nature of the service to be provided, the type of construction or use of facilities required, the name, address, and telephone number of the person or entity seeking to provide the service, and the name, address, and telephone number of an authorized representative of the person or entity. 
(b)  The applicant shall also provide evidence in a form satisfactory to the city that it has the financial, legal, and technical qualifications necessary to provide the service for which it seeks a franchise, and that all required federal and state certifications have been applied for or granted. Certification by the South Carolina Public Service Commission shall be sufficient evidence of such qualifications. 
(c)  In considering whether to grant consent or a franchise or to impose terms and conditions on the grant of consent or a franchise, the city may consider, without limitation, the following factors: 
(1)  The applicant's receipt of all required state and federal authorizations; 
(2)  The capacity of the streets to accommodate the applicant's proposed facilities; 
(3)  The damage or disruption, if any, of public or private facilities, improvements, or landscaping if a franchise or license is granted; 
(4)  The effect on public health, safety, or welfare if consent or a franchise is granted; 
(5)  The availability of alternate routes and locations for the proposed facilities; 
(6)  Whether the imposition of certain terms and conditions or the failure to grant the requested consent or a franchise would prohibit or have the effect of prohibiting the ability of the Applicant to provide any interstate or intrastate telecommunications services; and 
(7)  Any other factor relating to whether the grant of consent or a franchise impinges on the city's right to manage its streets. 
(d)  An applicant for consent or a franchise shall submit with its application a fee in the amount of $1,000.00 in partial compensation to the city for processing the application. 
(e)  If the city approves the application, the provider shall reimburse the city for any reasonable costs and expenses in excess of the fee specified in subsection (d), above, including attorneys' fees, incurred by the city to review and evaluate the application and prepare and negotiate a consent agreement or franchise agreement with the provider, including the costs of any publication as provided in section 20.5-5. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 4, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-5. - Consent agreement or franchise agreement. 
(a)  As a condition of the grant of consent or a franchise, the provider shall enter into a consent agreement or franchise agreement with the city. 
(b)  The required agreement shall contain such additional terms and conditions as are not in conflict with the terms of this chapter as may be necessary and appropriate for the particular circumstances of the provider and its use of and impact on city streets. 
(c)  The consent agreement or franchise agreement shall be adopted as an ordinance by the city prior to the initiation of any construction or the delivery of any service. 
(d)  A consent agreement or franchise agreement may be amended from time to time upon agreement of the city and the provider. 
(e)  The telecommunications provider shall pay to the city or on behalf of the city the cost of any publication required by law. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 5, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-6. - Construction and maintenance. 
(a)  Application. Prior to beginning construction of any telecommunications facility, including any curb cut or pavement cut, the applicant shall obtain permission from the department of public works of the city to carry out construction activities in the city's streets, and shall comply with all requirements of that department or any other ordinance or code applicable hereto. 
(b)  Construction plan. Prior to beginning construction, the applicant shall submit a plan describing the proposed construction. The plan shall specify: 
(1)  The design of any telecommunications facilities to be constructed or utilized; 
(2)  A map showing the precise location of any telecommunications facility to be constructed or utilized and any appurtenant facilities such as poles, attachments, guy wires, and the like; 
(3)  The timetable for completion of construction, including any phases of construction; 
(4)  Such other information as will provide the city with pertinent information relating to the construction of the telecommunications facilities, including any pertinent information requested by the city. 
(c)  Prior authority. Prior to beginning construction, the applicant shall have received all necessary regulatory authority to construct a telecommunications facility or provide telecommunications service from the South Carolina Public Service Commission, the Federal Communications Commission, or other appropriate state or federal agency. Evidence that it has received such regulatory authority, or that such authority is not required, shall be filed with the city. 
(d)  Standards of construction. The method of construction, workmanship used, and materials utilized in the construction shall conform to all applicable federal, state, and local statutes, rules, regulations and ordinances. All work shall be performed in a safe, thorough, and reliable manner using materials of good and durable quality so as not to create a hazard or dangerous condition on the streets. If, at any time, it is determined by the city or any other agency or authority of competent jurisdiction that any telecommunications facility presents a danger to the public health, safety or welfare, then the telecommunications provider shall, at its own cost and expense, after reasonable notice from the city, promptly correct all such conditions. 
(e)  Maintenance and repair. Any telecommunications facility constructed or utilized pursuant to a consent agreement or franchise agreement shall be maintained and repaired in accordance with the standards and under the terms and conditions set out in the preceding paragraph and such other terms and conditions as shall appear in this chapter or the agreement. 
(f)  Minimal disruption. Construction, maintenance and repair of the telecommunications facilities shall be conducted in such a manner as to minimize any interference with or disruption of the city's streets, traffic, residences, businesses and institutions. Where underground construction is required by subsection (i), below, the provider shall be obligated to use trenchless technology in appropriate circumstances as determined by the city's director of public works. 
(g)  Restoration. Any disturbance of the city's streets shall be repaired and restored by the telecommunications provider at its expense to a condition as good as that prevailing before the work causing such disturbance was commenced. If at any time the city determines that any restoration performed by the provider is deficient to the extent that it poses a threat to the safety of the public, the city shall have the right to undertake emergency repairs or other protective actions as may in its opinion be necessary and the provider shall reimburse the city for all costs of such repair or other actions. If any restoration performed by the telecommunications provider does not comply with the standards established in this section, the city may, after ten days written notice to the provider, perform necessary repairs to bring the restoration up to such standards and the provider shall reimburse the city for all costs of such repair. 
(h)  Location of facilities. Poles and other facilities shall be located to the extent feasible in such a way as to minimize their effect on the visual landscape and on other aesthetic considerations and so as to minimize inconvenience. 
(i)  Burial of facilities. It is the intent of city council that all utility facilities, including all telecommunications facilities, be underground in all areas of the city as quickly as is technically and economically feasible. All providers who enter into a franchise agreement or consent agreement with the city shall acknowledge that they will be required to place all facilities underground at their own expense upon the occurrence of any of the following: 
(1)  Immediately in any area of the city where all existing electric, telephone, and cable television lines are currently underground or where such lines are scheduled to be placed underground within one year. 
(2)  Within three years after the expiration, earlier termination, or material amendment of the existing electric franchise granted to the South Carolina Public Service Commission (Santee Cooper). The Santee Cooper franchise will expire under its terms on June 30, 2005. 
(3)  At such time as the city requires all holders of existing telephone, electric, and cable franchises or consent agreements to place their facilities underground. If the city establishes the requirement in a specific area of the city this provision shall apply to all facilities in that area. If the city establishes this requirement city-wide it shall apply to all providers city-wide. 
(4)  During the pendency of any litigation which may be brought by a competitor that has the effect of delaying the placement of that competitor's facilities underground, a provider may elect, at its own risk, to install above ground facilities within any area subject to the litigation, but will be required to place its facilities underground at its own expense upon a final determination of the litigation that upholds the requirement to place the facilities underground. 
In extreme circumstances city council may, by ordinance, grant permission for the installation of limited aboveground facilities if council finds that underground installation would be technically impractical or cause extreme economic hardship. In all cases similarly impacted providers shall be treated similarly. 
Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit or discourage agreements between providers and the city to provide incentives for the placement of facilities underground earlier than herein provided. 
(j)  Co-location; sharing of pole space and conduits. To the maximum extent feasible, a telecommunications provider constructing a new transmission line or other facility, or expanding an existing line or facility, shall utilize existing pole space or conduit facilities. The owner of any existing facility shall to the extent permitted by law and consistent with any pole attachment regulations of the public service commission, the Federal Communications Commission or other appropriate agency, permit the telecommunications provider to utilize its poles or conduits. 
(k)  Movement of facilities. A telecommunications provider shall be required to temporarily disconnect or relocate any of its facilities at its own expense when required by the city by reason of traffic conditions; public safety; or the construction, installation or repair of any public road, highway, building, park or other public project. The provider shall cooperate with any other public utility authorized by the city to provide utility service utilizing the city's streets. To the extent any removal or relocation is required for the benefit of any party other than the city, the provider may require payment of the actual cost of the removal or relocation by the benefitted party. 
(l)  Tree trimming. The zoning ordinance of the city provides that an annual permit may be issued to a provider exempting the provider from the provisions of the city's tree protection ordinance, but requires that the provider shall nevertheless conform its tree-trimming practices to the 1995 ANSI A300 Standards. The provider shall give the city zoning administrator 24-hours notice prior to undertaking any tree trimming. The zoning administrator may choose to observe any tree trimming performed by a provider and, if the required standards are not complied with, take all necessary enforcement action the administrator determines to be appropriate pursuant to the zoning ordinance. In the event a provider is found to have repeatedly violated the required standards in performing tree trimming, the city may also pursue any of the remedies in sections 20.5-17 and 20.5-18. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 6, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-7. - Performance bond. 
(a)  Prior to the start of construction, the provider shall post a performance bond, satisfactory to the city, in the city's favor, to ensure faithful performance of the terms and provisions of the consent agreement or franchise agreement and any approved construction plan filed with the city pursuant to subsection 20.5-6(b). The bond shall be equivalent to ten percent of the total cost of the construction as provided in the construction plan. 
(b)  In the event the provider fails to comply with this chapter or the franchise agreement, or to complete the construction in a safe, timely, and competent manner, after notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure, the city may recover, jointly and severally from the principal and surety of the bond, any damages or loss suffered by the city as a result, including the full amount of any compensation, indemnification, or cost of removal or abandonment of any property of the provider, plus a reasonable allowance for attorneys' fees, up to the full amount of the bond. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 7, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-8. - Term of franchise for providers. 
    A franchise agreement shall be for a term not exceeding ten years. In determining the term of a franchise, it is the intent of the city that the term be established so that all telecommunications franchises shall expire on approximately the same date. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 8, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-9. - Fees. 
(a)  Amount. In consideration of the city's grant of authority to utilize the city's streets for the provision of telecommunications services and for other good and valuable consideration, the telecommunications provider shall pay a franchise fee to the city in the following amounts: 
(1)  A telecommunications provider who provides service to residents, businesses or institutions in the city shall pay one percent of its annual gross revenues derived from its provision of telecommunications service in the city. Payment of this franchise fee is in addition to any business license tax that the provider is required to pay for the privilege of conducting business in the city. 
(2)  A telecommunications provider who provides service solely to persons outside the geographic boundaries of the city by utilizing a transmission line shall pay the city a reasonable annual fee based upon an installation fee and a charge per linear foot of transmission line that traverses the city's rights-of-way or based upon such other method as the city deems appropriate. Such fee and the method of payment shall be established in the consent agreement. 
(b)  Time of payment. All fees due and owing shall be paid on a biannual basis on or before August 15 of each year for the first six months of the calendar year and on or before February 15 of each year for the second six months of the preceding calendar year. 
(c)  Late payment. In the event that any payment is not actually received by the city on or before the date due under this chapter, interest thereon shall accrue from such date until received at the rate of ten percent per annum. 
(d)  Calculation of payments. All payments made to the city shall be accompanied by a statement certified as true by an appropriate employee of the provider or lessee explaining the basis of the calculation on which the payment was made. 
(e)  Payments. Payments shall be made by certified check to the City of Myrtle Beach, c/o City Finance Director, P.O. Box 2468, 937 Broadway/City Hall, Myrtle Beach, South Carolina 29578-2468 or by wire transfer to an account of the city designated in writing by the city finance director. 
(f)  Public disclosure. The payment of any fee under this section shall be publicly disclosed. 
(g)  Audit. Upon reasonable notice, the city shall have the right to inspect the telecommunications provider's books and records that are reasonably necessary for the city to determine compliance with this section. Such records shall not include any records relating to the existence or content of communications of the provider's customers which are protected from disclosure by federal or state law. A telecommunications provider shall maintain sufficient financial records governing its operation in the city to allow the determination of gross revenues and to otherwise document accurate payment of fees. To the extent permitted under the South Carolina Freedom of Information Act, the city shall maintain the confidentiality of such records. 
(h)  Fees not a tax. The fees provided in this section are not taxes and are separate from, and in addition to, any and all federal, state, local, and city taxes as may be levied, imposed, or due from a telecommunications provider or lessee, its customers or subscribers, or on account of the lease, sale, delivery, or transmission of telecommunications services; provided that no fee imposed by this section shall be imposed in violation of state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 9, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-10. - Indemnification. 
(a)  As a condition of the grant of consent or a franchise, the telecommunications provider shall agree to indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the city, its officers, boards, commissions, agents, and employees (collectively the "indemnified parties") from and against any and all lawsuits, claims, causes of action, actions, liabilities, demands, damages, judgments, settlements, disability, losses, expenses (including attorneys' fees and disbursements of counsel) and costs of any nature that any of the indemnified parties may at any time suffer, sustain or incur arising out of, based upon, or in any way connected with the provider's operations, the exercise of the consent or franchise herein granted or the breach by the provider of its obligations under this chapter and the consent agreement or franchise agreement or based upon or in any way connected with the activities of the provider, or their subcontractors, employees, and agents. The provider shall be solely responsible for and shall indemnify, defend, and hold the indemnified parties harmless from and against any and all matters relative to payment of the provider's employees, including compliance with Social Security and withholdings requirements. 
(b)  The indemnification obligations of the provider set forth in this chapter are not limited in any way by the amount or type of damages or compensation payable by or for the provider under workers' compensation, disability or other employee benefit acts, acceptance of insurance certificates required under any consent agreement or franchise agreement, if any, or the terms, applicability or limitations of any insurance held by the provider. 
(c)  The city does not, and shall not, waive any rights against the provider which it may have by reason of the indemnification provided for in this chapter because of the acceptance by the city, or the deposit with the city by provider, of any of the insurance policies described in this chapter. 
(d)  The indemnification of the city by a provider provided for in this chapter shall apply to all damages and claims for damages of any kind suffered by reason of any of the provider's operations referred to in this chapter regardless of whether or not such insurance policies shall have been determined to be applicable to any such damages or claims for damages. 
(e)  A provider shall not be required to indemnify the city for negligence or misconduct on the part of the city or its officials, boards, commissions, agents, or employees, provided that the provider shall be responsible for its proportionate share of any damages or claims resulting from any negligent act or omission. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 10, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-11. - Insurance. 
    As a condition of the grant of any franchise under this chapter, the provider shall, during the term of the franchise, at its sole expense, procure and maintain the following insurance coverage or equivalent self-insurance: 
(1)  General liability insurance: General Liability insurance or a program of self-insurance acceptable to the city. If provider elects to purchase commercial insurance in compliance with this provision, the insurance carrier shall be licensed to do business in the state and carry an A.M. Best & Co. rating of not less than "A". In either event, the coverage shall be a comprehensive broad form or its equivalent providing coverage with a minimum combined single limit of liability of $2,000,000.00 per occurrence. The policy or policies shall include, but shall not be limited to coverage for bodily injury, personal and advertising injury, property damage, products-completed operations, blanket contractual liability, underground collapse or explosion, professional errors and omissions, independent contractors and pollution liability. 
(2)  Automobile liability insurance. Automobile Liability insurance or a program of self-insurance acceptable to the city and approved by the state. If provider elects to purchase commercial insurance in compliance with this provision, the insurance carrier shall be licensed to do business in the state and carry an A.M. Best & Co. rating of not less than "A". In either event, the coverage shall be provided on the "Business Auto" form providing a combined single limit of liability of $2,000,000.00 per accident for bodily injury or property damage. 
(3)  Worker's compensation and employers liability. Workers' compensation and employers liability insurance policy or a program of self-insurance acceptable to the city and approved by the state. If the provider elects to purchase commercial insurance in compliance with this provision, the insurance carrier shall be licensed to do business in the state and carry an A.M. Best & Co. rating of not less than "A". In either event the coverage shall provide the following minimum limits of liability. Each accident: $2,000,000.00; disease-policy limit: $2,000,000.00, and disease-each employee: $2,000,000.00. 
(4)  General. 
a.  All policies shall be endorsed to provide the city with 30 days prior written notice of cancellation, modification or reduction in limits. 
b.  All insurance coverage or self-insurance stipulated herein shall be primary to any insurance policies or self-insurance program maintained by the city, which shall be excess and non-contributing. 
c.  The city shall incur no responsibility for the payment of any premiums or to comply with the claim-reporting requirements of provider's insurance policies or self-insurance program. 
d.  The city, its officers, employees and agents shall be named as an "additional insured" on provider's general liability insurance policy or under its self-insurance program. 
e.  Provider shall ensure that its contractors, subcontractors, and agents performing under authority of this franchise provide equivalent insurance coverages or are covered under the terms of provider's policies or self-insurance program. 
f.  The franchise granted to provider shall be an "insured contract" under the terms of provider's insurance policies or self-insurance program. 
g.  The policies or self-insurance program shall provide the standard form of cross-liability. 
h.  The blanket contractual liability shall be subject to the standard exclusions of contractual liability included in a Insurance Services Office (ISO) endorsement as to bodily injuries, personal injuries, and property damage. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 11, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-12. - Renewal. 
(a)  A telecommunications provider that seeks to renew its consent agreement or franchise agreement granted by the city pursuant to this chapter shall submit an application for renewal to the city no more than 365 and no less than 180 days before expiration of its franchise. The applicant shall provide such necessary information to show that it meets the requirements for renewal set out in subsection (b), below. 
(b)  In considering whether to grant a renewal request, the city shall consider whether the telecommunications provider: 
(1)  Has complied with the terms of this chapter and its consent agreement or franchise agreement; 
(2)  Has promptly cured any violation of this chapter or breach of its consent agreement or franchise agreement; 
(3)  Has fully and promptly paid any franchise fees or other compensation required by the city and any taxes imposed by the state or the city; 
(4)  Agrees to meet such additional requirement as may be imposed by the city in a competitively neutral and nondiscriminatory way; and 
(5)  Has cooperated with the city in carrying out the terms and conditions of this chapter and the franchise or license agreement and has provided such pertinent information as the city has requested throughout the term of the agreement. 
The city shall also consider any other matter that is relevant to the renewal of the franchise or license. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to refuse to renew any franchise for any reason, provided that the city shall comply with Section 253 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. 
(d)  If it chooses not to renew the consent agreement or franchise agreement, the city shall state its reasons in writing and provide the telecommunications provider with a copy. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 12, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-13. - Removal. 
(a)  Within 30 days following written notice from the city, any telecommunications provider or other person that owns, controls, or maintains any unauthorized telecommunications facility or related appurtenances on, in, under or above the streets shall, at its own expense, remove such facilities and appurtenances from the streets. 
(b)  A telecommunications facility is unauthorized if the franchise of the applicable telecommunications provider has expired or has never been obtained, if the facility has been abandoned, or if the construction of the facility was not in compliance with this chapter and the consent agreement or franchise agreement. A utility pole shall be deemed to be abandoned whenever all wires, lines, cables, and other facilities have been removed from the pole for a period of 30 days or more. 
(c)  Any abandoned utility pole which is not removed by the telecommunications provider as provided in this section may, after ten days written notice, be removed by the city. In the event of such removal by the city, the telecommunications provider shall pay the city for all costs incurred by the city to have the pole removed. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 13, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-14. - Transfer; transfer of control. 
(a)  Any person granted a consent agreement or a franchise agreement pursuant to this chapter ("grantee") shall not sell, transfer, lease, assign, sublet or dispose of, in whole or in part, either by forced or by involuntary sale, or by ordinary sale, consolidation, merger or otherwise, the consent or franchise agreement or any of the rights or privileges granted thereunder without the prior consent of the city council, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Evidence provided to the city of approval by the state public service commission shall be acceptable for compliance with this section. 
(b)  A grantee who seeks to take any of the actions specified in subsection (a), above, shall notify the city at least 90 days in advance of such anticipated action. In addition to providing notice of the proposed action, grantee and the proposed transferee, lessee, assignee, subletee, purchaser, or other entity ("transferee") shall also provide the following information at the time of such notice: 
(1)  Complete information setting forth the nature, terms and condition of the proposed transaction; and 
(2)  Information evidencing the transferee's legal, technical and financial qualifications. 
Within 20 days of a request by the city, the grantee and transferee shall also provide such other information pertinent to the proposed transaction as may be required by the city. 
(c)  Within 60 days of receiving all the information it has requested, the city shall take action on the proposed transaction. If the city disapproves the proposed transaction, it shall state its reasons in a resolution of the city council. If the city approves the proposed transaction, but with conditions, it shall likewise state the conditions in a resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Failure to obtain the approval of the city council as required by this section may be deemed a forfeiture of the applicable franchise by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 14, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-15. - Existing telecommunications providers. 
(a)  A telecommunications provider delivering service within or without the geographic limits of the city as of the effective date of this chapter who previously has been awarded a franchise may continue to operate according to the terms of the franchise it has been awarded. 
(b)  Any telecommunications provider who as of the effective date of this chapter is delivering service without a franchise shall submit an application pursuant to section 20.5-4 of this chapter within 90 days of the effective date. The provider shall also submit a written statement indicating that it accepts the terms and conditions of this chapter while its application is pending and that it shall pay all appropriate fees retroactive to the effective date. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 15, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-16. - Forfeiture. 
(a)  If, in the city's judgment, a telecommunications provider is or may be in violation or breach of any material term or condition of this chapter or consent or franchise agreement pursuant hereto, the city shall notify the provider of the suspected violation or breach. Upon notification, the provider shall supply to the city within 30 days all information and documentation the city requests with respect to the suspected violation or breach and shall make such statement to the city as it wishes in an effort to explain or mitigate the violation or breach. 
(b)  If the city is not satisfied with the information, documentation, and explanation of the provider, it may make a finding of a breach or violation and notify the provider of such finding. Thereafter, the provider shall have a reasonable period of time (the "cure period") as determined by the city to take such steps as are necessary to cure the violation or breach. 
(c)  If, at the conclusion of the cure period, the city determines that there remains a breach or violation of this chapter or consent or franchise agreement pursuant hereto, the city shall schedule a hearing before the city council or a duly authorized committee or representative of the council for the purpose of making a final determination as to whether a violation or breach exists. At the hearing, the provider, representatives of the city, and the public may present evidence relevant to the alleged violation or breach. 
(d)  At the conclusion of the hearing, or within 14 days thereafter, the city council shall takes such steps as it deems appropriate, including one or more of the following: 
(1)  Pursuing any of the remedies available to it as provided in section 20.5-17; 
(2)  Ordering the provider to take such steps as are necessary to cure the violation or breach on pain of forfeiture; 
(3)  Declaring a forfeiture of the consent or franchise and ordering the provider to take such steps as are necessary to remove its telecommunications facilities from the city's streets. 
(e)  If the provider is dissatisfied with the decision of the city, it may seek relief in the circuit court in and for Horry County. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 16, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-17. - Enforcement; penalties. 
(a)  A violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor subject to a penalty within the jurisdictional limits of a municipal court in the state. 
(b)  The city may seek injunctive relief or abatement orders in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  The city may pursue any of the remedies in this chapter separately or in conjunction with one another. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 17, 6-23-98) 
Sec. 20.5-18. - General provisions. 
(a)  Captions. The captions to sections throughout this chapter are intended solely to facilitate reading and shall not affect the meaning or interpretation of this chapter. 
(b)  No recourse against the city. Without limiting such immunities as the city or any other person may have under applicable law, a telecommunications provider awarded consent or a franchise under this chapter shall have no recourse whatsoever against the city or its officials, members, boards, commissions, agents or employees for any loss, cost, expense, liability or damage arising out of any action undertaken or not undertaken pursuant to any provision or requirement of this chapter or because of the enforcement of this chapter or the city's exercise of its authority pursuant to this chapter, or other applicable law, unless such loss is a direct consequence of the failure or refusal of the city to perform its agreement hereunder, or unless such recourse is expressly authorized by statute, this chapter, or other ordinance. 
(c)  Force majeure. In the event a telecommunications provider's performance of any of the terms, conditions, obligations or requirements of this chapter is prevented or impaired due to any cause beyond its reasonable control, such inability to perform shall be deemed to be excused for the period of such inability and no penalties or sanctions shall be imposed as a result thereof, provided that the provider has notified the city in writing within ten days of its discovery of the occurrence of such an event. Such causes beyond the provider's reasonable control shall include, but shall not be limited to, acts of God, civil emergencies, and labor unrest or strikes. 
(d)  Non-waiver of remedies. The failure of the city to take any action to enforce any violation or breach of this chapter shall not be deemed a waiver of its right to subsequently enforce any identical or similar violation or breach. 
(e)  Severability. If any portion of this franchise is declared invalid by any court, agency, commission, legislative body, or other authority of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent portion, and such declaration shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof, which remaining portions shall continue in force and effect. 
(f)  Notices and filings. All notices required by this chapter to be provided to the city shall be provided in writing to the city clerk. All filings shall be made with the city clerk unless otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-31, § 18, 6-23-98) 
Chapter 21 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; planning and development, ch. 15; streets and sidewalks, ch. 19; subdivision regulations, ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Municipal utilities generally, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-610 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approving authority means the director of engineering and public services of the city. 
    Connection fee means a nonrecurring, nonrefundable charge related to the impact on the system as measured by equivalent residential units (ERUs). 
    Connection (sewer) means attachment of the customer's line to the sewer service lateral. 
    Connection (water) means attachment of the customer's line to the water service line. 
    Customer means any person, corporation, or other legal entity who is the beneficiary of the water and/or sewer services, or who is utilizing the water and/or sewage system of the city. 
    Sewer service lateral means that portion of pipe which runs from the main to the customer's property line. 
    System (sewer) means the facilities and all appurtenances constructed (or accepted), operated, and maintained by the city for sewage disposal purposes. 
    System (water) means the facilities and all appurtenances constructed (or accepted), operated, and maintained by the city for the delivery of water. 
    Tap charge (sewer) means a nonrecurring, nonrefundable charge related to the costs of installing the sewer service lateral. 
    Tap charge (water) means a nonrecurring, nonrefundable charge related to the costs of installing the water connection. 
    Tenant means nonowner occupant of a property and/or building served by water and/or sewer by the city. 
    Water service line means the city's line, meter, and appurtenances from the main to the customer's property line. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-2. - Enabling act. 
    The city may furnish water and sewer service to persons for reasonable compensation. These charges may be fixed from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-1) 
Sec. 21-3. - Council to establish water and sewer rates. 
    Water and sewer rates shall be set by the city council and shall be subject to change at the discretion of the city council. These rates shall be kept on file and shall be subject to inspection or explanation upon request. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-2) 
Sec. 21-4. - Illegal connection. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to connect to, tamper with, or tap the water system, fire protection system, or sewer system except with the specific authorization of the approving authority. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to establish, or allow to be established, any actual or potential connection or structural arrangement between the public water supply and any potentially hazardous source or system, as determined solely by the approving authority, unless a backflow prevention device is installed, at the customer's expense, between the public water supply and the source of potential contamination. Such backflow prevention device shall be a SCDHEC-approved device. Each device shall be tested by a South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (SCDHEC) certified tester after installation and before use by the customer, and each device shall be tested at least once annually by a SCDHEC-certified inspector. The customer shall provide the city with a written report of the inspection and testing results as prepared by the SCDHEC-certified tester making the inspection and test. All costs associated with inspection and testing of such devices shall be borne by the customer. Noncompliance with these requirements, within 30 days of notification by the city, shall result in termination of water service. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-3) 
State Law reference- Tapping water main without permit, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-1160. 
Sec. 21-5. - Tampering with metering devices. 
    It shall be unlawful to tamper with or change any water meter or sewer metering device without written permission of the approving authority. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-4) 
Sec. 21-6. - Service termination and illegal reconnection. 
(a)  The city shall have the authority to terminate or disconnect water and/or sewer services and remove any metering device to any premises for failure to pay water and/or sewer service charges at the time they are due and payable. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to reconnect or reestablish water or sewer services when such services have been terminated or disconnected by the city without specific authorization of the approving authority. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-5) 
Sec. 21-7. - Water connection fees and deposits.

(c)  When new use is planned for property that previously has been provided with water services, a credit shall be given based on the ERU schedule set forth in subsection (a) of this section. It shall be the responsibility of the customer to provide acceptable information with regards to determination of previously existing development for credit purposes. If the new use would result in a water connection fee less than the fee for the former use, no refund will be paid. Credits shall run with the property; provided, however, a property owner within a planned unit development relocating an existing business to property owned by that same person or entity within a planned unit development created by the city and local governmental entities may transfer credits. For the purpose of this section, "local governmental entities" shall mean only Horry County, Horry County municipalities, Horry County special purpose authorities and the Horry County Department of Education.
