(f)  Whenever the meter is removed at the request of the customer or ownership of a serviced property changes, the customer's deposit, without interest, shall be returned to the depositor within 45 days after first deducting all outstanding charges. 
(g)  The owner of rental property is required to pay a deposit for each property owned to secure the payment of usage and availability using the schedule listed in paragraph (e) under Utility Deposits-Owner. The deposit is not refundable until ownership of the rental property changes. Whenever an owner sells a rental property, the deposit with any accrued interest shall be refunded to the depositor after first deducting any outstanding charges associated with the property during any time that the rental property was vacant and not actively rented. During vacancy, the property owner shall be billed monthly for water and sewer if applicable as long as the water meter remains installed at the property. The owner of rental property or their designated agent has a responsibility to notify the city that a tenant has either vacated or been evicted from a rental property. Whenever a tenant vacates a rented structure or dwelling, the tenant's deposit, without interest, shall be returned to the depositor within 45 days after first deducting all outstanding charges. 
(h)  In the event of a transfer of water service not requiring an increase in meter size, an owner or tenant who has a deposit with the city and whose account is in good standing shall not be required to pay an additional deposit or increase thereof. In the event a larger size meter is required, the owner or renter shall meet the applicable deposit. In the event a smaller meter size is required, an applicable refund shall be given. 
(i)  The owner-occupant of a single family primary residence shall be given a refund of the utility deposit paid after three years unless the customer has had two consecutive 30-day arrearages, or more than two non-consecutive arrearages, in the past 36 months. The owner of a non-residential property, non-residential rental property, or residential rental property shall not be entitled to a refund of the utility deposit until ownership of said property changes. A tenant shall not be entitled to a refund of the utility deposit until such time the utility account is closed. 
(j)  Simple interest on utility deposits at the current passbook rate shall be credited to each customer required to make such deposit during the time it is held by the city, provided that no interest need be accrued unless the deposit is held longer than six months. The accrual of interest shall be credited to each customer's deposit account annually and shall accumulate until the deposit is refunded to the customer. 
(k)  The public works department may approve the use of a fire hydrant meter and such meter will be utilized for water on a short term, temporary basis. A person or an entity requesting a fire hydrant meter will be required to complete an application and pay the required deposit. A fire hydrant meter shall be issued for a period not to exceed 90 days. Any extension of the 90-day period must be approved by the public works department. Customers shall be billed in accordance with section 21-10. Relocation of a hydrant meter within the 90-day period will be subject to a fee that must be paid prior to the installation of the hydrant meter at the new location. Any damage to the hydrant meter shall be the responsibility of the customer and the cost of the repair or replacement will be added to the customer's utility account. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-7; Ord. No. 2000-38, 10-10-00; Ord. No. 2003-44, 6-10-03; Ord. No. 2003-78, 10-28-03; Ord. No. 2004-21, 3-23-04; Ord. No. 2016-70, 9-13-16; Ord. No. 2018-40, §§ 1, 2, 6-26-18; Ord. No. 2018-42, §§ 1, 2, 6-26-18) 
Sec. 21-8. - Sewer connection fees. 
(a)  For each new sewer connection to the system, a person, corporation or other legal entity applying for sewer service shall pay a connection fee based upon the equivalent residential units (ERUs) schedule as set forth in section 21-7(a). 
(b)  The connection fee per ERU for sewer is as follows: 
Fiscal Year Fee Inside City Fee Outside City 1992 $919.00 $1,379.00 1993  965.00  1,448.00 1994 1,013.00  1,520.00  
(c)  For each new sewer connection to the system, a person, corporation or other legal entity shall, in addition to the connection fee, pay a tap charge under the following schedule, except where a sewer service lateral exists and is utilized: 
Service Pipe Size     Tap Charge 
6? ..... $445.00  
The tap charge shall be increased annually at the rate of five percent on July 1 of each fiscal year for a five-year period. Cost of other size service pipes to be installed shall be determined on the basis of direct and indirect labor, direct material and overhead. Service pipes larger than six inches in diameter must be authorized by the approving authority. 
(d)  When new use is planned for property that previously has been provided with sewer services, a credit shall be given based on the ERU schedule set forth in section 21-7(a). If the new use would result in a sewer connection fee less than the fee for the former use, no refund will be paid. Credits shall run with the property; provided, however, a property owner within a planned unit development relocating an existing business to property owned by that same person or entity within that planned unit development and local governmental entities may transfer credits. For the purpose of this section, "local governmental entities" shall mean only Horry County, Horry County municipalities, Horry County special purpose authorities, and the Horry County Department of Education. 
(e)  When a new use is planned for property that previously has been provided with sewer service, the existing sewer service lateral to the property line shall be used without relocation, with no sewer tap charge assessed; provided, however, a fee for inspection shall be charged. A tap charge will be assessed for installation of a new sewer service lateral to any property, if requested and approved, where a sewer service lateral already exists. In addition, a charge will be assessed for direct and indirect labor and material costs for abandonment of the existing, unused tap. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-8; Ord. No. 2003-78, 10-28-03) 
Sec. 21-9. - Water and sewer use charges. 
(a)  Water user charges. The charges for use of city water shall be set from time to time by the council and a schedule of such charges is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  Sewer user charges. The charges for sewer service shall be set from time to time by the council and a schedule of such charges is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(c)  The schedule of water and sewer user charges contains a minimum charge and a user charge for each size of water meter. The minimum charge includes the cost of availability, capacity, and maintenance of the system. On a monthly basis, each customer is billed the minimum charge for water and, if applicable, sewer. If additional consumption above the minimum is used, a user charge is calculated per 1,000 gallons of consumption as shown on the schedule of such charges on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-11; Ord. No. 2003-44, 6-10-03) 
Sec. 21-10. - Water and sewer billing. 
(a)  All customers shall be billed monthly. The due date for each monthly statement is defined as 15 working days from the date of billing. These bills shall include both the water and sewer service charge when applicable. The sewer charge is based on water consumption. 
(b)  If the monthly bill is not paid on or before the due date, the following occurs: If any bill remains unpaid ten days after the due date, all services to the customer shall be forthwith discontinued and remain discontinued until the full obligation, including the past due bill with penalty, the current service charge and, a meter reinstallation fee, if the meter has been removed. The fee for the meter reinstallation shall be set by the director of finance. If any bill remains unpaid ten days after the discontinuance of service, the meter will be subject to removal by the city. Prior to the removal of the meter, written notice shall be mailed to the customer and in the case of rental property, written notice shall also be mailed to the property owner or their designated agent. If the property owner's name is not on file, the property owner's notice will be mailed to the service address. A customer has the right to appeal a water and or sewer bill to the director of finance. The director of finance will determine any adjustment and the decision of the director of finance is final. 
(c)  If a water meter shall be removed for nonpayment of a bill or removed at the request of the customer, a fee based on direct and indirect labor, direct material, and overhead shall be assessed for reinstallation of the meter for that property. Regardless of the reason the meter was removed, at the time of reinstallation, the customer shall be required to comply with all the existing city policies relating to the provision of water and/or sewer that would apply if service were being provided to the property for the first time. 
(d)  No water or sewer service shall be furnished or rendered free of charge to any person, corporation, or other legal entity, except for internal city operations. 
(e)  If a metering device fails to operate during any billing period, or portion thereof, the city shall render a bill for the same amount of water and/or sewer billed to that account during the same period of the previous year, unless satisfactory documentation for less usage can be provided. If a failure occurs during the first year of the account history, a reasonable bill based on available historical account information will be rendered. 
(f)  If a balance remains on a utility account after it has been closed, the city has the right pursuant to the South Carolina Setoff Debt Collection Act to collect any sum due and owed by the customer through offset of the customer's state income tax refund. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-6; Ord. No. 2000-38, 10-10-00; Ord. No. 2003-44, 6-10-03) 
Sec. 21-11. - Restricted account for improvements. 
    Monies generated from connection fees shall be placed into a restricted account for use in capital improvements to the system of which 50 percent shall be reserved for plant expansion. Accrued interest on the account shall be considered revenue to the city. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-12) 
Sec. 21-12. - Irrevocable letter of credit. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, commercial development with a construction period of greater than six months shall be allowed the use of an irrevocable letter of credit for water and sewer connection fees. Payment for water tap charge and sewer tap charge is due with the irrevocable letter of credit prior to the issuance of the building permit. The irrevocable letter of credit shall remain in full force and effect until a certificate of occupancy, temporary or final, is issued. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-13; Ord. No. 93-57, 10-12-93) 
Sec. 21-13. - Capacity commitment limitation. 
    If actual construction has not been initiated within 12 months from the date of issuance of the connection charge calculation ticket for water and/or sewer services, then the ticket shall become null and void and 90 percent of the purchase price paid shall be refunded by the city. For the purpose of this chapter, "date of issuance" shall be that date upon which the connection charge calculation ticket is completed by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-14) 
Sec. 21-14. - Acceptance of wastewater into city sewage facilities. 
    The city shall not accept wastewater into the sewage facilities from any property if the supply of water to that property does not originate from the city's water distribution system. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-10) 
Sec. 21-15. - Civil penalties. 
    Any person or entity violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to civil penalties in accordance with S.C. Code 1976, § 6-11-285, and such procedures as may be enacted as part of the city's industrial pretreatment program. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-15) 
Sec. 21-16. - Existing areas within the city without available services. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, any person owning developed property within the corporate limits without sewer service adjacent to the property line on May 7, 1985, shall, upon availability of such service adjacent to the property, pay sewer connection fees under the existing rate schedule immediately prior to the enactment of this section, which is $400.00 per ERU; provided, however, connection is made pursuant to section 21-32(b) and use of the property has remained the same. Should use of the property change after May 7, 1985, and prior to connection to the sewer system, applicable fees and charges shall be calculated under the then-existing rate schedule. 
(b)  Further, notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, any person, organization or other legal entity owning developed property within the corporate limits with, on May 7, 1985, an existing sewer service lateral to the property line or sewer main running adjacent to the property and not having received notification by the city pursuant to section 21-32(b) shall be exempt from a connection fee upon connecting to the sewer system; provided, however, the use of the property has remained the same. Should use of the property change after May 7, 1985, and prior to connection to the system, applicable fees and charges shall be calculated under the then-existing rate schedule. For the purpose of this section, "developed" shall mean a current use of the property for which a septic tank is required and in place. 
(Code 1980, § 4-1-9) 
Secs. 21-17-21-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SEWER USE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to establish, maintain, etc., sewerage system, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-810. 

Sec. 21-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abnormal industrial wastes means any industrial waste having a suspended solids or BOD content in excess of that normally found in municipal sewage. For the purposes of this chapter, any waste containing more than 250 mg/l of suspended solids or having a BOD in excess of 250 mg/l shall be deemed an abnormal industrial waste, regardless of whether or not it contains other substances in concentration differing appreciably from those normally found in municipal sewage. 
    Abnormal wastewater means the same as abnormal industrial wastes, except it may originate from a nonindustrial customer. 
    Approving authority means the director of engineering and public services of the city. 
    BOD means the quantity of oxygen utilized in biochemical oxidation of the organic matter of sewage or industrial wastes under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. It shall be determined by one of the acceptable methods described in the latest edition of Standard Methods for Examination of Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection. 
    C means Celsius degrees. 
    Chain of custody means a permanent record identifying who took the sample, who transported it, to whom the sample was delivered for analysis, along with the time and dates of such transactions. 
    Control manhole means a manhole giving access to a building sewer at some point before the building sewer discharges and mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
    Cooling water means the water discharged from any use, such as air conditioning, cooling, or refrigeration, during which the only pollutant added to the water is heat. 
    County means Horry County or any agency or department thereof. 
    Customer means any individual, bulk user, firm, company, association, society, corporation, municipal government, special purpose district, government installation, group or agency who are the beneficiaries of the water and sewer services or who are utilizing the water and/or sewer system of the city. 
    EPA means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Garbage means animal and vegetable wastes and residues from preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food and from the handling, processing, storage, and sale of food. 
    Grease means fat, oils, waxes, and other related constituents found in wastewater. 
    Industrial wastewater means the liquid discharged as a result of the processes employed in industrial establishments or which exceeds the concentration of normal municipal wastewater. 
    Infiltration/inflow and/or unpolluted wastewater means extraneous water, including, but not limited to groundwater, stormwater, surface water, pool drains, cooling water, or other waters or wastes which do not originate from an approved domestic or industrial wastewater connection. 
    Major contributing industry means a customer of the publicly owned treatment works that has a flow of 25,000 gallons or more per average work day; has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in the standards issued under section 307(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972; and is found by the city, in connection with the issuance of an NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
    May is permissive; shall is mandatory. 
    Meter measurement means the act of or result of determining the quantity of water supplied to a customer by an instrument or device used for such purpose and approved by the city. 
    mg/l means milligrams per liter. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Normal wastewater means wastewater discharged into the sanitary sewer in which the average concentration of total suspended solids and BOD is not more than 250 mg/l, total phosphorus is not more than 15 mg/l, and total Kjeldahl nitrogen is not more than 18 mg/l. 
    NPDES means the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System, as defined in section 402 of the Federal Water Pollution Act and any subsequent amendment thereto. 
    pH means the negative logarithm of the concentration of hydrogen ions in gram moles per liter of solution determined by acceptable laboratory procedures. 
    POTW means publicly owned treatment works, meaning the city wastewater treatment system. 
    Pretreatment means the treatment of wastewater by the customer before introduction into the publicly owned system. 
    Pretreatment standards means all applicable rules and regulations contained in the Code of Federal Regulations, as published in the Federal Register, under section 307 of Public Law 92-500 and any amendment thereto. 
    Private system means a system of sanitary sewers not owned, maintained, or operated by the city and which sewers deliver wastewater to the public sewer facilities. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the waste from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means pipe or conduit carrying wastewater, of which owners of abutting properties shall have the use, subject to control by the city. 
    Sanitary sewer means a public sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or industrial wastes, or a combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface water, groundwater, and other unpolluted wastes are not intentionally passed. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, businesses, buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such groundwater, surface water, and stormwater as may be present. 
    Sewage facilities means intercepting sewers, sewage treatment works, pumping stations, outfall sewers, and appurtenances owned, operated, and maintained by the city for sewage disposal purposes. 
    Standard methods means "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," prepared and/or subsequently amended and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    Stormwater means any flow occurring during or immediately following any form of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom. 
    Suspended solids mean solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage, industrial waste, or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtration. The quantity of suspended solids shall be determined by one of the acceptable methods described in the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association. 
    Trap means a device designated to skim, settle, or otherwise remove grease, oil, sand, flammable wastes, or other harmful substances. 
    User charge means the charge levied on all users, including but not limited to persons, firms, corporations or governmental entities that discharge and/or cause or permit the discharge of sewage into the public sewerage facilities. 
    User surcharge means the charge made, in excess of the user charge, for all wastewater which exceeds the loading defined for normal wastewater, infiltration/inflow which exceeds allowable system infiltration or inflow rates, and/or unpolluted wastewater. 
    Wastewater means a combination of water-carried waste from residences, businesses, buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present. 
(Code 1980, § 4-2-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-32. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except as permitted under provisions of this article. 
(b)  All improved property within the corporate limits of the city is hereby required, at the owner's expense, to have toilet facilities installed therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so, except at specific locations where the approving authority may waive this requirement in writing, upon a determination that the alternative measures will not be hazardous to public health. If sewer service has been provided by a septic tank prior to notice to connect to the public sewer, the owner, as a condition of connecting to the public sewer, shall properly abandon the existing septic tank by pumping out all wastes and completely filling the tank with soil or removing the tank altogether. This septic tank abandonment or removal requirement shall be enforced, within the city, by the construction services department through the sewer connection permitting and inspection process, under the authority of the plumbing inspector. For properties outside of the city, verification of proper septic tank abandonment must be provided by the county building department. 
(c)  Except as provided in this article, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)  Unless otherwise provided in this article, all persons within the city's service area deemed unable to be connected to the sanitary sewer system shall provide appropriate septic tanks for sewage disposal, in full compliance with the state board of health rules and regulations governing waste disposal systems and those provisions of the city's subdivision regulations which establish minimum lot sizes where septic tanks may be permitted or minimum lot area requirements of the state board of health, whichever of the two is the greater size. 
(e)  Direct service connections made to the city's sanitary sewer system shall be made only by duly authorized and approved agents of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 4-2-2) 
Sec. 21-33. - Private sewage disposal. 
    The disposal of wastewater by means other than the use of the available sanitary sewage system shall be in accordance with local, county, and state law. The disposal of sewage by private disposal systems shall be permissible only in those instances where service from the available sanitary sewage system is not available. 
(Code 1980, § 4-2-3) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate the use of privies, septic tanks, etc., S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-2010. 
Sec. 21-34. - Building sewers and connections. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or openings into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the approving authority. 
(b)  There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  A, for residential and commercial service; and 
(2)  B, for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by plans, specifications, and/or other information considered pertinent in the judgement of the approving authority. Under permit A, cost per tap will be based upon the schedule as set forth in section 21-8. Under permit B, fees will be established on each industrial application based on tap, user charge, and industrial cost recovery. 
(c)  All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify and hold the city harmless from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the design or installation of the building sewers. 
(d)  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot, and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building, and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(e)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, upon examination and test by the approving authority, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(f)  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society for Testing and Materials and Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(g)  Whenever practical, as determined by the approving authority, the construction of buildings requiring sewer service or the renovation/change-of-use of existing buildings in an area currently served by gravity sewer, or an extension of the gravity sewer system available to serve the area, shall be performed in such a manner that will permit the building sewers to drain by gravity flow to the public sewer or extension thereof. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means, at the owner's expense, and discharged to the building sewer. Operation and maintenance of such lifting system shall be the responsibility of the owners. 
(h)  No person shall connect any roof downspout, exterior/interior foundation drain, areaway drain, pool drain, cooling water drain, or other source of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(i)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and the WPCF Manual of Practice. 
(j)  All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved in writing by the approving authority. 
(k)  The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the approving authority or his representative when the building sewer is ready for connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the approving authority. 
(l)  All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city at the expense of the customer or applicant. 
(m)  All cafes, restaurants, food preparation establishments, transient accommodations with efficiency apartments containing kitchen facilities, convenience stores or grocery stores with food preparation facilities, and cafeterias within industrial, medical, and retail facilities shall install a grease trap on all kitchen waste lines. All domestic waste shall bypass the grease trap. 
(n)  All gas stations, automotive repair shops, equipment maintenance shops, and car wash facilities whose floor drain system connects to the public sewer system shall install an oil/grease separator trap on all lines receiving flow from the floor drain system. 
(o)  Grease traps and oil/grease separators of the underground vault type shall be installed on the outside of buildings and within the confines of private property. Mechanical grease traps and oil/grease separators required for use at shopping malls and on existing buildings, where the installation of a grease trap or oil/grease separator outside the building is not practical, as determined by the approving authority, may be approved for installation on the inside of the building. 
(p)  Grease traps and oil/grease separators of the underground vault type installed outside the building shall be designed to provide a one-half-hour detention of peak instantaneous flows from the establishment, as calculated from ultimate loadings based on fixture count and trap influent line diameter. The trap shall be of the two compartment type and comply with current public utilities department specifications. Mechanical and/or aboveground grease traps and oil/grease separators shall be mechanical devices which are solely dependent upon the owner or the employees of the owner or operator to prevent discharge from the device which exceeds regulated sewage limitations. 
(q)  Grease traps and oil/grease separators shall be cleaned periodically by the owner or operator of the facility. Failure to perform periodic cleaning which results in the discharge of wastewater beyond the 100 mg/l grease or oil limits which causes damage to public properties or system appurtenances or results in a stoppage of the public sewer facilities shall constitute a misdemeanor and subject the owner or operator to assessment of civil penalties. 
(r)  All damages and costs associated with or caused by the inadequate maintenance of a grease trap or oil/grease separator or the lack of a required grease trap or oil/grease separator, whether such costs are incurred by the city or through contingent liability, shall be paid by the owner or operator of the facility. 
(s)  If the approving authority determines that a discharge of grease or oil into the public sewer system is causing or has a significant potential to cause damage, operational problems, increased operational costs, or increased liability in the proper operation of the public sewage facilities, the customer shall be required to install an approved grease trap or oil/grease separator within 90 days after written notification by the city. Installation of a grease trap or oil/grease separator shall be made at the owner's expense, and the city shall retain the right to inspect and approve the installation of the facility. 
(t)  Owners or operators of private sewer systems discharging wastewater to the public sewage facilities, whether by gravity or pressure flow, shall maintain and operate such private system in a manner that prevents the discharge of abnormal wastewater, stormwater, excessive groundwater infiltration, improperly shredded garbage, excessive amounts of sand or other settleable solids, cooling water, and other unpolluted wastewater into the public sewage facilities. 
(u)  All damages and costs associated with or caused by the improper operation or maintenance of a private sewer system incurred by the city in providing remedial maintenance, repair, engineering and administrative efforts, surveillance and sampling, legal fees, and cleanup equipment, which are directly attributable to the inadequate maintenance or operation of the private system, shall be paid by the owner or operator of the private system. 
(v)  Upon the acquisition by the city of an easement for the purpose of construction and maintenance of sewer lines, the city may require all trees, shrubs, buildings, or other obstructions to remain outside the easement area. Original clearing of the easement area may be done by the city. Any violation of this clearance policy, after construction, may result in the removal as necessary of any obstruction at the owner's expense. 
(w)  Any private septic tank truck operator who wishes to discharge the truck's wastes into the city sewer system must obtain a permit for each truck from the city and pay the current fee. 
The septic waste dump site facility at the wastewater treatment plant shall be the only site approved for discharging waste material. Discharging waste material in other locations is strictly prohibited and violation shall be deemed a misdemeanor. In addition, a second violation shall result in the revocation of the discharge permit. 
Charges for discharging such septic tank trucks shall be set from time to time by the council and a schedule of such charges is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1980, § 4-2-4) 
Sec. 21-35. - User charge system. 
(a)  User charge shall be the charge levied on all users including, but not limited to, persons, firms, corporations, or governmental entities that discharge, cause, or permit the discharge of sewage into the public sewerage facilities. 
(b)  The user charge shall, at a minimum, reflect the costs of operation and maintenance of the public sewerage facilities. 
(c)  Each user shall pay at a minimum its proportionate share of operation and maintenance cost based on volume flow. 
(d)  The city shall review, not less often than every two years, the sewage contributions of users, the total costs of operation and maintenance of the sewerage facilities, and the user charge system. The city shall revise the user charge if necessary to accomplish the following: 
(1)  Maintain the proportionate distribution of operation and maintenance costs among users as provided in this section. 
(2)  Generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and maintenance costs necessary for the proper operation and maintenance of the sewerage facilities. 
(e)  All flow to the sewerage facilities not directly attributable to the users, i.e., infiltration/inflow, shall be distributed among all users of the sewerage facilities based upon the volume of flow of the users. 
(f)  Each user shall be notified at least annually in conjunction with a regular bill of the rate and that portion of the user charge which is attributable to operation and maintenance of the sewerage facilities. 
(Code 1980, § 4-2-5) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide a sewerage charge, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-670; municipal authority to establish a sewer service and sewer connection charge, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-2030. 
Sec. 21-36. - Private system surcharge. 
(a)  All private sewer systems discharging wastewater into the city public sewerage facilities, whether by gravity or pressure flow, shall pay a surcharge for the discharge of abnormal waste and/or excessive amounts of unpolluted waters discharged into the city system which are directly attributable to the operation of the private system. 
(b)  Private systems discharging wastewater to the public sanitary sewerage system having an average suspended solids content in excess of 250 mg/l and/or an average five-day BOD in excess of 250 mg/l shall pay a surcharge based on excessive strength of their wastes as follows: 
(1)  BOD: Five-day, 20 degrees Celsius BOD in excess of 250 mg/l, shall be charged $0.28 per excess pound or fraction thereof. 
(2)  Suspended solids: Suspended solids in excess of 250 mg/l shall be charged $0.27 per excess pound or fraction thereof. 
(c)  Private systems discharging to the public sanitary sewage system having an average unpolluted wastewater flow exceeding 200 gallons per inch of pipe diameter per mile of pipe per day, as determined from standard methods of examining sewer systems for groundwater infiltration and stormwater inflow, shall pay a surcharge based on the quantity of unpolluted water being discharged at 11/2 times the current user charge per 1,000 gallons of normal wastewater discharge to the public system in their area. 
(d)  Private systems discharging wastewater to the public sewerage facilities in excess of quantity of infiltration/inflow limitations may obtain a written waiver of surcharge fee from the city for a period not to exceed five years. To obtain such waiver, the owner or operator of the private system shall enter into an agreement with the city to spend an amount equal to or exceeding one-third of the estimated surcharge cost in subsection (c) of this section on an annual basis for private sewer system rehabilitation work directly related to abating the excessive unpolluted wastewater flows subject to the surcharge. As part of this surcharge waiver agreement, the owner or operator of the private system shall obtain prior approval from the city for all rehabilitation work and provide annual documentation of system rehabilitation costs. At the end of the waiver period, the city will retain the right to evaluate the private system for compliance to limitations and assess a surcharge if limitations are exceeded. 
(Code 1980, § 4-2-6) 
Sec. 21-37. - Enforcement procedures. 
    Any person or entity violating any provision of this article shall be subject to enforcement procedures as may be enacted in article III of this chapter, including civil penalties in accordance with S.C. Code 1976, § 6-11-285. 
(Code 1980, § 4-2-7) 
Secs. 21-38-21-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER CONSERVATION 

Sec. 21-51. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of certain terms and phrases used in this article shall be as follows: 
    Construction means new building or addition as well as remodeling or renovating existing buildings which includes the installation or replacement of toilets, toilet reservoirs, etc. 
    Faucet means any inside fixture or device for drawing water from a pipe within the jurisdiction of the City of Myrtle Beach. 
    Shower means any water apparatus or device that provides a shower or booth in which public water is used to shower the body. 
    Toilet means any waste disposal fixture or system used for discharging human wastes to the public sewer system. 
    Water means all water delivered, conveyed or distributed by means of the city public water system. 
    Water-saving devices means such fixtures or measures or apparatus that restrict the flow or use of water provided by the public water system. Such devices may include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Plastic dams means devices that dam off a portion of a toilet reservoir and are adjusted to maintain a lower water level in the toilet reservoir. 
(2)  Improved float assemblies means devices that are installed in toilet reservoirs that are adjusted to maintain a lower water level in the toilet reservoir. 
(3)  Faucet aerators means devices within the faucet that mix water with air and provide an even flow to reduce the amount of water flowing from a faucet. 
(4)  Spray taps means devices used in lavatory sinks and wash basins that cause water to be sprayed from the tap rather than issuing forth a single stream. 
(5)  Flow-control devices means devices used in shower heads and faucets that limit or restrict the amount of flow of water used. 
(6)  Water-saving toilets means toilets that contain a smaller water reservoir than that of a conventional toilet. 
(Code 1980, § 4-3-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-52. - Use of water-saving devices required. 
    All construction of any type which connects to the public water system shall not be initiated or provided with service by the city unless the owner has complied fully with the prescribed water conservation measures. 
(Code 1980, § 4-3-2) 
Sec. 21-53. - Water-saving devices for construction. 
    All interior plumbing for construction shall meet the following minimum design criteria. 
(1)  Toilets, urinals and associated flush valves shall not use more than 31/2 gallons per flush. 
(2)  Shower heads shall contain inserts, valves, devices or orifices that restrict flow to a maximum of approximately three gallons per minute at 60 pounds per square inch (psi) or such other water-saving devices available that may be approved by the city. 
(3)  Kitchen and lavatory faucets shall have aerators or laminar flow devices together with flow-control inserts, valves, devices or orifices that restrict flow to a maximum of approximately two gallons per minute at 60 psi, or such other available water-saving devices may be approved by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 4-3-3) 
Sec. 21-54. - Water-saving measures for new developments. 
    All new parks, median strips, landscaped public areas and landscaped areas surrounding condominiums, townhouses, apartments, industrial parks and shopping centers planning to install an irrigation system shall have a well-balanced automatic irrigation system designed by an engineer or other certified person approved by the city and shall be operated by electrical time controller stations set for early morning irrigation between 1:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. Landscaping covering clay-type soils and sloped areas shall be equipped with low-output sprinkler heads permitting a slow water application rate. The city may, upon the written request of an applicant, waive any part or all of the requirements of this section if it finds that the areas to be landscaped are too small or do not otherwise justify the automatic irrigation system and other measures herein referenced. It is recommended where irrigation systems are designed that first consideration be given to an onsite shallow well water source system. If a shallow well water source is to be used, in no case shall such system be interconnected with the city's public system. Upon the submission of substantial documentation that an onsite water source system cannot be employed, then consideration will be given to the approval of the herein referenced provisions. 
(Code 1980, § 4-3-4) 
Sec. 21-55. - Water-saving technology. 
    The city code enforcement division shall periodically publish and have on file for public review an up-to-date list of water-saving fixtures, devices or measures that address the intent of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 4-3-5) 
Sec. 21-56. - Water-saving devices for existing users. 
    For each water service customer the city may require the use of water-saving devices which may include, but not necessarily be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Plastic dams or improved float assemblies for reducing toilet flush water requirements; 
(2)  A flow-control device (restrictor) for reducing shower flow rates; 
(3)  A dye tablet or tablets for determining if a toilet tank leaks; 
(4)  Other pertinent conservation measures. 
(Code 1980, § 4-3-6) 
Sec. 21-57. - Leaks. 
    Leaks occurring in any plumbing system, or part thereof, which is served water from the city water system shall be repaired within five days after such leak is detected. 
(Code 1980, § 4-3-7) 
Sec. 21-58. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to fixtures or devices which have been ordered by or are in the inventory of contractors, suppliers or developers on or before December 3, 1985. Nor shall they apply to fixtures, such as safety showers and aspirator faucets, which, in order to perform a specialized function, cannot meet the standards herein specified. Contractors, suppliers and/or developers shall provide such evidence as invoices, purchase orders and bills of lading dated prior to December 3, 1985, if requested by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 4-3-8) 
Sec. 21-59. - Enforcement procedure and penalties. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating any provision of this article shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations and take corrective action. The city reserves the right to refuse water services to the offenders. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)  Any person who knowingly makes any false statement, representation or certification in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this article, or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders the water conservation devices inoperable shall, upon conviction, be punished in accordance with section 1-9. 
(d)  In addition to the aforesaid, wherever a person violates any provision of this article or fails to comply with any order of the city, the city may apply to the court of the state for the issuance of an injunction restraining the person violating the article or failing to comply with the order. 
(Code 1980, § 4-3-9) 
Sec. 21-60. - Water-saving devices and techniques.

(1)  Low-flush (31/2 gallon/flush) toilets. 
(2)  Shower head flow control-3 gpm.

(Code 1980, § 4-3-10) 
Secs. 21-61-21-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INDUSTRIAL PRETREATMENT PROGRAM 

Sec. 21-76. - Introduction. 
(a)  The General Pretreatment Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution (40 CFR 403), as promulgated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in June 1978, outlines the regulations for a pretreatment program. The EPA delegated to the state department of health and environmental control the administration and enforcement authority for the state pretreatment program. 
(b)  The objectives of the pretreatment program are to: 
(1)  Prevent the introduction of pollutants into publicly owned treatment works (POTW) which will interfere with plant operations and/or the disposal or use of municipal sludge. 
(2)  Prevent the introduction of pollutants into a POTW which will pass through the treatment works or be incompatible with the POTW. 
(3)  Improve opportunities to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludges. 
(4)  Enforce applicable EPA categorical standards. 
(5)  Provide for equitable distribution of the cost for treatment of waste discharged to the POTW. 
(c)  The state pretreatment program is divided into two phases. Phase I deals primarily with an evaluation of the existing situation at a POTW. Phase IA consists of surveying the nondomestic dischargers and evaluating the type, volume and strength of the discharged waste to the POTW. Phases IA and IB of the pretreatment program for the city was submitted in June 1989 to the state department of health and environmental control. The state department of health and environmental control advised that a complete pretreatment program would be required for the city POTW. 
(d)  This report addressed the development of the pretreatment program that will be implemented by the city and fulfills phase II of the state pretreatment program. Phase II concerns the organization, staffing, funding and adoption of ordinances that are needed to implement the pretreatment program. 
(e)  Composite sampling was conducted on the influent and effluent of the city wastewater treatment facility and one major industrial discharger. No excessive amounts of substances could be found in the plant influent that would be detrimental to treatment plant performance. Historically, the wastewater treatment facility is well within the NPDES permit limits for BOD and TSS. Very low concentrations of metals were present in both the waste treatment plant influent and effluent. 
(f)  Sampling of the major dischargers to the system was undertaken to determine the characteristics of their discharges. The results of the sample analyses are available for review at the city engineering and public services department. 
(Ord. No. 92-06, § 4-3-0, 1-28-92) 
Sec. 21-77. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abnormal industrial wastes means any industrial waste having a suspended solids or BOD content in excess of that normally found in municipal sewage. For the purposes of this article, any waste containing more than 250 mg/l of suspended solids or having a BOD in excess of 250 mg/l shall be deemed an abnormal industrial waste regardless of whether or not it contains other substances in concentration differing appreciably from those normally found in municipal sewage. 
    Abnormal wastewater means the same as "abnormal industrial wastes" except it may originate from a nonindustrial customer. 
    Approving authority means the director of public services and engineering of the city. 
    BOD means the quantity of oxygen utilized in biochemical oxidation of the organic matter of sewage or industrial wastes under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. It shall be determined by the methods specified in 40 CFR 136. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection. 
    C means Celsius degrees. 
    Chain of custody means a permanent record identifying who took the sample, who transported it, and to whom the sample was delivered for analysis, along with the time and dates of such transactions. 
    Composite sample means: 
(1)  An influent or effluent portion collected continuously over a specified period of time at a rate proportional to the flow. 
(2)  A combination of not less than eight influent or effluent grab samples collected at regular, equal intervals over a specified period of time, properly preserved, and composited by increasing the volume of each aliquot in proportion to flow. If continuous flow measurement is not used to composite in proportion to flow, the following method will be used: Take an instantaneous flow measurement each time a grab sample is collected. At the end of the sampling period, sum the instantaneous flow measurements to obtain a total flow to determine the partial amount (percentage) of each grab sample to be combined to obtain the composite sample. 
(3)  A combination of not less than eight influent or effluent grab samples of equal volume but at variable time intervals that are inversely proportional to the volume of the flow. That is, the time interval between aliquots is reduced as the volume of flow increases. 
(4)  A combination of not less than eight influent or effluent grab samples or constant, equal volume collected at regular, equal time intervals over a specified period of time, while being properly preserved. 
Continuous flow or the sum of instantaneous flows measured and averaged for the specified compositing time period shall be used with composite sample results to calculate quantity. 
    Control manhole means a manhole giving access to a building sewer at some point before the building sewer discharges and mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
    Cooling water means the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, during which the only pollutant added to the water is heat. 
    County shall mean Horry County or any agency or department thereof. 
    Customer means any individual, bulk user, firm, company, association, society, corporation, municipal government, special purpose district, government installation, group or agency which is the beneficiary of the water and sewer services or which is utilizing the water and/or sewer system of the city. 
    EPA means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Garbage means animal and vegetable wastes and residue from preparation, cooking and dispensing of food; and from the handling, processing, storage and sale of food. 
    Grab sample means an individual discrete or single influent or effluent portion of at least 100 milliliters collected at a time representative of the discharge and over a period not exceeding 15 minutes and retained separately for analysis. Instantaneous flow measured at the time of grab sample collection shall be used to calculate quantity. 
    Grease means fat, oils, waxes and other related constituents found in wastewater. 
    Industrial wastewater means the liquid discharged as a result of the processes employed in industrial establishments or which exceeds the concentrations of normal municipal wastewater. 
    Infiltration/inflow and/or unpolluted wastewater means extraneous water including, but not limited to, groundwater, stormwater, surface water, pool drains, cooling water or other waters or wastes, which do not originate from an approved domestic or industrial wastewater connection. 
    May is permissive; "shall" is mandatory. 
    Meter measurement means the act of or result of determining the quantity of water supplied to a customer by an instrument or device used for such purpose and approved by the city. 
    mg/l means milligrams per liter. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Normal wastewater means wastewater discharged into the sanitary sewer in which the average concentration of total suspended solids and BOD is not more than 250 mg/l, total phosphorus is not more than 15 mg/l, and total Kjeldahl nitrogen is not more than 18 mg/l. 
    NPDES means the national pollutant discharge elimination system as defined in section 402 of the Federal Water Pollution Act and any subsequent amendment thereto; amendments of 1972 (Public Law 92-500). 
    pH means the negative logarithm of the concentration of hydrogen ions in gram moles per liter of solution determined by acceptable laboratory procedures. 
    POTW means publicly owned treatment works, meaning the city wastewater treatment system. 
    Pretreatment means the treatment of wastewater by the customer before introduction into the publicly owned system. 
    Pretreatment standards means all applicable rules and regulations contained in the Code of Federal Regulations as published in the Federal Register, under section 307 of Public Law 92-500 and any amendment thereto. 
    Private system means a system of sanitary sewers not owned, maintained or operated by the city and which sewers deliver wastewater to the public sewer facilities. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the waste from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means pipe or conduit carrying wastewater of which owners of abutting properties shall have the use, subject to control by the city. 
    Sanitary sewer means a public sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface water, groundwater and other unpolluted wastes are not intentionally passed. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, businesses, buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such groundwater, surface water and stormwater as may be present. 
    Sewage facilities includes intercepting sewers, sewage treatment works, pumping stations, outfall sewers and appurtenances owned, operated and maintained by the city for sewage disposal purposes. 
    Significant industrial user means: 
(1)  Industrial users subject to categorical pretreatment standards under 40 CFR 403.6 and 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N; and 
(2)  Any other industrial user that: discharges an average of 25,000 gallons per day or more of process wastewater to the POTW, excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater; contributes a process wastestream, which makes up five percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant; or is designated as such by the control authority on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
    Significant noncompliance means a violation of discharge limitations that meets one or more of the following criteria or a violation of compliance schedule milestone as follows: 
(1)  Chronic violations in which 66 percent or more of all the measurements taken during a six-month period exceed, by any magnitude, the daily maximum limit or the average limit for the same pollutant parameter; 
(2)  Technical review criteria (TRC) violations in which 33 percent or more of all the measurements taken during a six-month period for the same parameter equal or exceed the product of the daily maximum limit or the average limit multiplied by the applicable TRC; TRC = 1.4 for BOD, TSS, fats, oils, and grease; and TRC = 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH; 
(3)  Any other violation of a pretreatment effluent limit (daily maximum or monthly average) that the city determines has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass through, including endangering the health of the treatment system personnel or the general public; 
(4)  Any discharge causing imminent endangerment to human health/welfare or to the environment or resulting in the city's use of its emergency authority to halt or prevent such a discharge; 
(5)  Failure to meet, within 90 days after the scheduled date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a wastewater discharge permit or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction or attaining final compliance; 
(6)  Failure to provide, within 30 days after the due date, required reports such as baseline monitoring reports, 90-day compliance reports, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; 
(7)  Failure to accurately report noncompliance; 
(8)  Any other violation or group of violations which the city determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
    Standard methods means Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater prepared and/or subsequently amended and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation. Note: All laboratory analyses must now be done in accordance with the methods specified in 40 CFR 136. 
    State means the State of South Carolina or any agency or department thereof. 
    Stormwater means any flow occurring during or immediately following any form of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface or are in suspension in water, sewage, industrial waste or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtration. The quantity of suspended solids shall be determined by one of the acceptable methods referenced in 40 CFR 136. 
    Trap means a device designed to skim, settle or otherwise remove grease, oil, sand, flammable wastes or other harmful substances. 
    User charge means the charge levied on all users including, but not limited to, persons, firms, corporations or governmental entities that discharge and/or cause or permit the discharge of sewage into the public sewerage facilities. 
    User surcharge means the charge made, in excess of the user charge, for all wastewater which exceeds the loading defined for normal wastewater, infiltration/inflow which exceeds allowable system infiltration or inflow rates, and/or unpolluted wastewater. 
    Wastewater means a combination of water-carried waste from residences, businesses, buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present. 
(Ord. No. 92-06, § 4-3-1, 1-28-92) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-78. - Procedures for approving pretreatment systems. 
    All pretreatment systems, including equalization basins, must be permitted by the industrial wastewater division of the state department of health and environmental control before they are constructed. The POTW shall review the proposed pretreatment system to ensure that the monitoring or sampling points are acceptable and the proposed system will be compatible with their pretreatment program requirement before forwarding the plans to the state department of health and environmental control for review. 
(Ord. No. 92-06, § 4-3-2, 1-28-92) 
Sec. 21-79. - Procedures for developing discharge limits. 
(a)  After evaluating the results of the nondomestic waste survey and the results of any sampling that was completed, the POTW will establish discharge limits for any pollutants that should be controlled. When developing the discharge limits, the following shall be taken into consideration: 
(1)  Categorical limits. These are established as federal requirements. The POTW cannot establish limits that are less stringent than these requirements but can establish more stringent limits. 
(2)  Hazardous waste management regulations. If the sewage sludge solids are to be disposed of as a nonhazardous waste, the sludge solids must be nontoxic, not ignitable, nonreactive, and noncorrosive. If the sewage sludge solids contain any of the materials in Appendix IV of the Hazardous Waste Management Regulations, they may be designated as hazardous wastes and will be required to be disposed of in a hazardous waste landfill. Appendix IV of the Hazardous Waste Management Regulations and additional information concerning the parameters that the POTW should analyze for in the sewage sludge solids are available for review at the department of engineering and public services. 
(3)  Drinking water standards. If a pollutant is passing through the wastewater treatment plant but is not a categorical pollutant, a limit for that pollutant shall be established to prevent the concentration of that pollutant in the receiving stream from exceeding the drinking water standard for that pollutant. 
(4)  Construction permit limits. These are limits that shall be established as a condition for a nondomestic discharger to obtain from the state department of health and environmental control a permit to construct a pretreatment system. 
(5)  Water quality standards. These are limits for pollutants to prevent an impact on the aquatic life in the receiving stream. These limits may be found in the EPA publication Quality Criteria For Water. 
(6)  NPDES limits. These are limits for the discharge from the POTW and are set by the state department of health and environmental control and the EPA. 
(7)  Operation and maintenance considerations. The POTW may find it necessary to impose a limit on a substance if it is causing interference in the treatment process or if it threatens the physical structure of the collection and treatment system. Examples of a substance that must need to be regulated are as follows: 
a.  Substances with a pH lower than 5.0 or which will cause corrosive damage to any part of the collection and treatment system. 
b.  Solid or viscous substances in amounts which will cause an obstruction to the flow in the collection system or interference in the treatment plant. 
c.  Pollutants which create a fire or explosion hazard in the POTW, including, but not limited to, wastestreams with a closed cup flashpoint of less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21. 
d.  Petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin in amounts that will cause interference or pass through. 
e.  Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems. 
f.  Any trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by the POTW. 
(8)  Health and safety consideration. These are limits that may be needed to protect the health and safety of the operators or maintenance workers. 
(9)  POTW considerations. Any unique situation where a POTW may establish discharge limits for a reason other than the above. 
(10)  Dilution. The limits should specifically prohibit dilution of the discharge. Mass limits in pounds/day should be established for each pollutant to be regulated. 
(b)  Procedure for developing a discharge limit for a contaminant shall include these steps: 
(1)  Determine the amount of the contaminant that enters the treatment plant and leaves the POTW in the effluent or the sewage sludge solids. 
(2)  Establish the maximum amount of the contaminant that can enter the wastewater collection and treatment system without violating the NPDES permit, interfering with approved sludge disposal, interfering with any of the treatment processes, endangering the physical structures of the collection and treatment system or endangering POTW personnel or the public health and safety. 
(3)  Determine the amount of the contaminant that may be present in the normal domestic sewage. 
(4)  Establish a safety factor for future growth in the community in the form of additional domestic dischargers and nondomestic dischargers. 
(5)  Subtract the amount of the contaminant contributed by the domestic dischargers and the amount saved for the safety factor from the maximum amount that can enter the wastewater treatment plant. 
(6)  Distribute the remaining amount of the contaminant equitably among the nondomestic dischargers that discharge the contaminants to the POTW. 
For a more detailed explanation of these steps, see Appendix D, available for inspection at the office of the department of engineering and public services. 
(c)  Once the pretreatment limits are proposed by the POTW, the nondomestic dischargers shall be advised of the proposed limits. This shall take the form of a written notification explaining the proposed limits and offering the discharger an opportunity to respond. When the affected dischargers are notified of the proposed limits, the POTW should also provide individual notification of the proposed limits to all interested persons or groups who have requested such notification. A public notice of the intent to adopt the proposed limits should be published in the local newspaper and an opportunity for the discharger or interested parties to respond must be provided. A public hearing is not required but there must be a procedure for receiving written or verbal comments. The procedure for developing the pretreatment limits and notifying the affected dischargers and interested individuals or groups will be followed each time a new standard or set of standards is established for a discharger or group of dischargers. 
(Ord. No. 92-06, § 4-3-3, 1-28-92) 
Sec. 21-80. - Prohibition and limitations on wastewater discharge. 
(a)  Prohibitions. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the city sewerage facilities or any connected treatment facilities any waste which contains any of the following: 
(1)  Oils and grease. Fats, wax, grease or oils of more than 100 mg/l, whether emulsified or not, or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 degrees and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (zero degrees and 65 degrees Celsius) at the point of discharge into the system. 
(2)  Explosive mixtures. Pollutants which create a fire or explosion hazard in the POTW, including, but not limited to, wastestreams with a closed cup flashpoint of less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21. If two successive readings on an explosion hazard meter, at the point of discharge into the sewer system, shall exceed five percent, or any single reading exceed ten percent, of the lower explosive limit (LEL) of the meter, it shall be presumed that this section has been violated. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides and sulfides. 
(3)  Noxious material. Noxious or malodorous solids, liquids or gases which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are capable of creating a public nuisance or hazard to life, or may prevent entry into a sewer for its maintenance and repair. 
(4)  Improperly shredded garbage. Garbage that has not been ground or commingled to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely in suspension under flow conditions normally prevailing in the public sewers. 
(5)  Radioactive wastes. Radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration that they are in noncompliance with regulations issued by the appropriate authority having control over their use and which will or may cause damage or hazards to the sewerage facilities or personnel operating the system. 
(6)  Solid or viscous waste. Solid or viscous wastes which will or may cause obstruction to the flow in a sewer, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewerage facilities. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, grease, uncombined garbage, animal guts or tissues, paunch manure, bones, hair, hides or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers, ashes, cinders, sand, spent limestone or marble dust, metal, glass, straw, shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, wastepaper, wood, plastic, tar, asphalt residues, residues from refining or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, and similar substances. 
(7)  Excessive discharge rate. Wastewaters at a flow rate which is excessive relative to the capacity of the treatment works and which would cause a treatment process upset and subsequent loss of treatment efficiency; or wastewaters containing such concentrations or quantities of pollutants that their introduction into the treatment works over a relatively short time period, sometimes referred to as slug discharges, would cause a treatment process upset and subsequent loss of treatment efficiency. 
(8)  Heavy metals and toxic substances materials. No heavy metals or toxic materials shall be discharged into public sewers without a written permit from the city specifying conditions of pretreatment, concentrations, volumes and other applicable provisions. In addition, no metallic or toxic substance which may interfere with the biological processes or efficiency of the collection, transmission, treatment and disposal facilities of the city shall be discharged to the public sewer. 
(9)  Unpolluted wastewaters. Any unpolluted wastewater which will increase the hydraulic load on the sewerage facilities. 
(10)  Discolored materials. Wastes with objectionable color not removable by the treatment process. 
(11)  Corrosive wastes. Any waste which will cause corrosion or deterioration of the sewerage facilities. All wastes discharged to the public sewer system must have a pH value in the range of 6 to 9. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, acids, sulfides, concentrated chloride and fluoride compounds and substances which will react with water to form acidic products. 
(12)  Abnormal industrial waste. As defined in section 21-77. 
(13)  Heat. No person shall discharge heated waste of any nature that may interfere with the proper operation of the sewerage facilities. Heat shall be deferred in accordance with 40 CFR 403.8 as presently existing or as may be amended in the future. 
(14)  Materials having potential impacts on effluents or residuals disposal. Any substance which may cause the POTW's effluent, or any other product of the POTW such as residues, sludges, or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process. In no case shall a substance discharged to the POTW cause the POTW to be in noncompliance with sludge use or disposal criteria, guidelines or regulations developed under section 405 of the Act; any criteria, guidelines or regulations affecting sludge use or disposal developed pursuant to the Solids Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or state criteria applicable to the sludge management method being used. 
(b)  Limitations. It is unlawful to discharge or convey to the public sewer any wastewater containing pollutants of such character or quantity that will: 
(1)  Not be amenable to treatment or will interfere with the sewerage facilities. 
(2)  Constitute a hazard to human or animal life, or to the stream or watercourse receiving the treatment plant effluent. 
(3)  Violate the federal pretreatment standards. 
(4)  Cause the treatment plant to violate its NPDES permit or other permits issued by the state department of health and environmental control. 
(c)  Dilution. Dilution of any wastewater discharge for the purpose of satisfying the requirements of this article shall be considered a violation of this article. If waste producers are found to be within article limits and the wastes produced create adverse effects or interfere with any waters due to the total pounds discharged of toxic substances, the approving authority shall establish additional or more stringent limits as deemed necessary. 
(d)  National categorical pretreatment standards. Certain industrial customers are now or shall become subject to categorical pretreatment standards promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency specifying quantities or concen- trations of pollutants or pollutant properties which may be discharged into the POTW. All industrial customers subject to a categorical pretreatment standard shall also be subject to the limitations established by this article or by the state. Upon promulgation of the federal categorical pretreatment standards for a particular industrial subcategory, the federal standard, if more stringent than limitations in this article, shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed under this article. The city shall notify in writing all affected customers of the applicable reporting requirements under 40 CFR 403.1. Compliance with categorical pretreatment standards for existing sources subject to such standards or for existing sources which become subject to such standards shall be within 180 days from the effective date of the standards unless a shorter compliance time is specified in the standard. Specific compliance schedules will be developed by the city and made a part of the industrial user's discharge permit. Compliance with categorical pretreatment standards for new sources shall be required upon initiation of a discharge. 
(Ord. No. 92-06, § 4-3-4, 1-28-92) 
Sec. 21-81. - Industrial waste surcharge. 
(a)  Established. All customers making discharges of industrial waste shall pay a charge to cover the cost of collection, transmission, treatment and disposal. When a permit application for industrial waste is approved, the city or its authorized representative shall issue a permit stating the terms of acceptance by the city and the basis of payment. In the event a customer discharges abnormal industrial waste into the public sanitary sewerage system having an average suspended solids content in excess of 250 mg/l, and/or an average five day BOD in excess of 250 mg/l, customers shall pay a surcharge based upon the excess strength of their wastes as follows: 
(1)  BOD. Five day, 20 degrees Celsius BOD in excess of 250 mg/l shall be charged $0.28 per excess pound or fraction thereof. 
(2)  Suspended solids. Suspended solids in excess of 250 mg/l shall be charged $0.27 per excess pound or fraction thereof. 
(b)  Review. The costs of treatment for each pound of BOD or suspended solids removed by each treatment works may be reviewed by the city at the end of each fiscal year. If a discrepancy exists between the actual costs as found by the city and the estimated costs, the city shall increase or decrease the surcharge rates sufficiently to cover only the projected actual costs for the ensuing year. 
(c)  Reduction. No reduction in sewerage service charges, fees or taxes shall be permitted by reason of the fact that certain industrial wastes discharged to the public sanitary sewerage system contain less than 250 milligrams per liter of suspended solids or 250 milligrams per liter BOD. Such charges in this section adopted may be amended or adjusted from time to time in accordance with the adoption of rates and charges established by the city. 
(d)  Special fees. Special fees shall be assessed as needed to recover costs associated with abnormal remedial maintenance and repair, engineering and administrative efforts, surveillance and sampling cost, legal fees, and cleanup equipment directly attributable to the industry causing such actions to be taken. 
(e)  Surveillance and sampling fees. In addition to the self-monitoring required by this article, the city may conduct annual and/or random surveillance and sampling. Annual surveillance will generally be limited to a plant inspection.
