g.  Reduce watering of lawns, plants, trees, gardens, shrubbery and flora on private or public property to the minimum necessary. Encourage outdoor watering to be done during off-peak hours. 
h.  Reduce the amount of water obtained from fire hydrants for construction purposes, fire drills or for any purpose other than fire-fighting or flushing necessary to maintain water quality; and 
i.  Limit normal water use by commercial and individual customers including, but not limited to, the following: 
1.  Serving water in addition to another beverage routinely in restaurants upon request only 
2.  Stop maintaining water levels in scenic and recreational ponds and lakes, except for the minimum amount required to support aquatic life; 
3.  Cease water service to customers who have been given a ten-day notice to repair one or more leaks and have failed to do so. 
(3)  Intensify maintenance efforts to identify and correct water leaks in the distribution system. 
(4)  Continue to encourage and educate customers to comply with voluntary water conservation. 
(c)  Severe drought phase. Upon notification by the drought response committee that a Severe drought condition is present and is expected to persist and/or upon determination by the City of Myrtle Beach that a severe water supply shortage exists, the City of Myrtle Beach will seek voluntary reduction in the use of water for all purposes and mandatory restrictions on non-essential usage and restrictions on times when certain water usage is allowed. Specifically, the goal during this phase is to achieve a reduction of 20 percent in residential water use, 20 percent in all other water use categories, and a reduction in overall water use of 20 percent. To accomplish these goals, the City of Myrtle Beach will take the following actions: 
(1)  Issue a proclamation to be released to the local media, the City of Myrtle Beach's customers and to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center that severe drought conditions are present. 
(2)  Provide written notification to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center and routinely publish in a newspaper of general circulation in the service area of the water system the voluntary conservation measures and mandatory restrictions to be placed on the use of water supplied by the utility, including: 
a.  Voluntary reduction of residential water use by the utility's customers to 65 gallons per person per day and a maximum of 250 gallons per household or REU per day. 
b.  Control landscape irrigation by the utility's customers by staggering watering times. 
c.  Mandatory restrictions on the use of water supplied by the utility for activities including: 
1.  Eliminate the washing down of sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts and other hard surfaced areas; 
2.  Eliminate the washing down of buildings for purposes other than immediate fire protection; 
3.  Eliminate the flushing of gutters; 
4.  Eliminate domestic washing of motorbikes, boats, cars, etc.; 
5.  Eliminate the use non-recycled of water to maintain fountains, reflection ponds and decorative water bodies for aesthetic or scenic purposes, except where necessary to support aquatic life; 
6.  Eliminate filling or maintaining public or private swimming pools; 
7.  Eliminate obtaining water from fire hydrants for construction purposes, fire drills or any purpose other than fire-fighting or flushing necessary to maintain water quality; and 
d.  Limit use of water by commercial and individual customers including, but not limited to, the following: 
1.  Serving water in addition to another beverage routinely in restaurants upon request only. 
2.  Stop maintaining water levels in scenic and recreational ponds and lakes, except for the minimum amount required to support aquatic life; 
3.  Limit irrigating golf courses and any portion of its grounds; 
4.  Cease water service to customers who have been given a ten-day notice to repair one or more leaks and have failed to do so; and 
5.  Limit expanding commercial nursery facilities, placing new irrigated agricultural land in production or post phoning planting or landscaping when required by site design review process. 
(3)  Intensify maintenance efforts to identify and correct water leaks in the distribution system. 
(4)  Continue to cease installation of new irrigation meters on the water system. 
(5)  Publicize widely the penalties to be imposed for violations of mandatory restrictions and the procedures to be followed if a variance in the restrictions is requested. 
(6)  Expand the use of education and public relations efforts and emphasize the penalties associated with violating the mandatory restrictions. 
(7)  Provide written notification weekly to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center regarding the success of the voluntary and mandatory restrictions. 
(d)  Extreme drought phase. Upon notification by the drought response committee that an extreme drought condition is present and is expected to persist and/or upon determination by the City of Myrtle Beach that an extreme water supply shortage exists based on the trigger levels, the City of Myrtle Beach's will impose mandatory restrictions in the use of water for all purposes and on the times when certain water usage is allowed. Specifically, the goal during this phase is to achieve a reduction of 30 percent in residential water use, 30 percent in all other categories of water uses and a reduction in overall water use of 30 percent. To accomplish these goals, the City of Myrtle Beach will take the following actions: 
(1)  Issue a proclamation to be released to the local media, the City of Myrtle Beach customers and to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center that extreme drought conditions are present; 
(2)  Provide written notification to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center and routinely publish in a newspaper of general circulation in the service area of the water system the mandatory restrictions to be placed on the use of water supplied by the utility, including: 
a.  Limiting residential water use to 55 gallons per person per day and a maximum of 225 gallons per household or REU per day. 
b.  Eliminate landscape irrigation by the utility's customers. 
c.  Mandatory restrictions on the use of water supplied by the utility for activities including: 
1.  Eliminate the washing down of sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts and other hard surfaced areas; 
2.  Eliminate the washing down of buildings for purposes other than immediate fire protection; 
3.  Eliminate the flushing of gutters; 
4.  No domestic washing of motorbikes, boats, cars, etc.; 
5.  Eliminate the use of water to maintain fountains, reflection ponds, and decorative water bodies for aesthetic or scenic purposes, except where necessary to support aquatic life. 
6.  Eliminate filling or maintaining public or private swimming pools; 
7.  Eliminate obtaining water from fire hydrants for construction purposes, fire drills, or any purpose other than firefighting or flushing necessary to maintain water quality; and 
d.  Limit normal water use by commercial and individual customers including, but not limited to, the following: 
1.  Stop serving water in addition to another beverage routinely in restaurants; 
2.  Stop maintaining water levels in scenic and recreational ponds and lakes, except for the minimum amount required to support fish and wildlife; 
3.  Stop irrigating golf courses and any portion of their grounds utilizing potable water from the City of Myrtle Beach Water System 
4.  Cease water service to customers who have been given a ten-day notice to repair one or more leaks and have failed to do so; and 
5.  Limit expanding commercial nursery facilities, placing new irrigated agricultural land in production, or planting or landscaping when required by site design review process. 
(3)  Intensify maintenance efforts to identify and correct water leaks in the distribution system. 
(4)  Continue to cease installation of new irrigation meters on the water system. 
(5)  Outline other conservation measures, examples are: 
a.  Consider placing a moratorium on the issuance of all new water service connections and contracts for all new water main extensions. As part of the public information process, provide notice to developers of the moratorium; 
b.  Encourage all residential water customers to voluntarily reduce overall monthly water usage to 70 percent of the customer's monthly average. If voluntary reduction of usage is not successful, the City of Myrtle Beach may, at its option, implement the following excessive use rate schedule for water: 
Tier I 0-210 gallons/REU regular rate Tier II 210-300 gallons/REU 1.5 times regular rate Tier III > 300 gallons/REU 2.0 times regular rate  
(6)  Publicize widely the penalties to be imposed for violations of mandatory restrictions and the procedures to be followed if a variance in the restrictions is requested. 
(7)  Expand the use of education and public relations efforts as conducted under the moderate and severe drought phase and emphasize the penalties associated with violating the mandatory restrictions. 
(8)  Provide written notification monthly to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center regarding the success of the mandatory restrictions. 
(e)  Rationing. If a drought threatens the protection of public health and safety, the City of Myrtle Beach is hereby authorized to ration water. 
(f)  Enforcement of restrictions. If any customer of the City of Myrtle Beach fails to comply with the mandatory water use restrictions of this ordinance, the customer shall be subject to penalties as established in section 1-9 of the City Code of ordinances. Law enforcement agencies and other authorized agencies or designated employees in the respective jurisdiction which is being supplied water by the City of Myrtle Beach shall diligently enforce the provisions of the drought response ordinance. 
(g)  Variances. Customers, who in their belief are unable to comply with the mandatory water use restrictions of this drought response ordinance, may petition the city manager or his designee for a variance from restrictions by filing a petition with the City of Myrtle Beach within ten working days after the issuance of the proclamation requiring water use restrictions. All petitions for variance shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the petitioner; 
(2)  Purpose of water usage; 
(3)  Special provision from which the petitioner is requesting relief; 
(4)  Detailed statement as to how the curtailment declaration adversely affects the petitioner; 
(5)  Description of the relief desired; 
(6)  Period of time for which the variance is sought; 
(7)  Economic value of the water use; 
(8)  Damage or harm to the petitioner or others if petitioner complies with the ordinance; 
(9)  Restrictions with which the petitioner is expected to comply and the compliance date; 
(10)  Steps the petitioner is taking to meet the restrictions from which the variance is sought and the expected date of compliance; and 
(11)  Other information as needed. 
In order for the variance to be granted, the petitioner must demonstrate clearly that compliance with the ordinance cannot be technically accomplished during the duration of the water supply shortage without having an adverse impact upon the best interests of the community. The City of Myrtle Beach is authorized to grant the request for variance. 
In addition, the City of Myrtle Beach is authorized to grant temporary variances for existing water uses otherwise prohibited under the ordinance if it is determined that failure to grant such variances could cause an emergency condition adversely affecting health, sanitation and fire protection for the public. No such variance shall be retroactive or otherwise justify any violation of this ordinance occurring prior to the issuance of the variance. Variances granted by the City of Myrtle Beach shall include a timetable for compliance and shall expire when the water supply shortage no longer exists, unless the petitioner has failed to meet specified requirements. 
(h)  Status of the ordinance. 
(1)  If any portion of this ordinance is held to be unconstitutional for any reason, the remaining portions of the drought response ordinance shall not be affected. 
(2)  The provisions of this ordinance shall prevail and control in the event of any inconsistency between this ordinance and other rules and regulations of the City of Myrtle Beach. 
(3)  Nothing in this ordinance shall be deemed to invalidate or be interpreted in a manner inconsistent with any covenants now in effect and given as security to holders of bonds secured by revenues of the system. 
(Ord. No. 2003-43, 6-10-03) 
Chapter 23 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 11; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12. 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-23-60; as to counties containing a city with a population in excess of 70,000, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-23-1210 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - [Valid authorization]. 
    No person shall operate any touring vehicle, pedicab or otherwise special vehicle for the purposes of transporting people for hire on any public street in the City of Myrtle Beach without possessing, in addition to any license required by any other law, a valid franchise authorizing the proposed operation. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 23-2. - Authority to franchise. 
    In its legislative discretion, the city council shall have the authority to review and approve or deny requests for touring vehicles, pedicab and special vehicle franchises, and may attach special conditions to any franchise in furtherance of the public health, safety and welfare, and shall have the authority to waive any of the criteria for one-time only special vehicle permits for special events. For cause shown and in furtherance of the public health, safety and welfare, the city council may revoke a franchise. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 23-3. - Application required. 
    Any person requesting a franchise for a touring vehicle, pedicab or special vehicle shall submit an application for consideration to the city manager. The application for consideration shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant, with pertinent business information, such as ownership, partners, and physical location. 
(2)  A description of the vehicle, including seating capacity, colors, murals or thematic devices. 
(3)  The proposed days of the week and hours of operation, and the beginning and ending dates during which the service will be offered. 
(4)  The proposed passenger pickup and delivery point. 
(5)  A description of where patrons may park their private vehicles (applicable to touring only). 
(6)  The rates proposed to be charged to patrons using the service. 
(7)  The proposed route over which the vehicle will operate. 
(8)  The speed the vehicle will travel. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 23-4. - Criteria for approval. 
    The proposed operation shall: 
(1)  Have a clearly defined route that will not create traffic congestion or adversely affect the character or privacy of a residential area. 
(2)  Have proposed pickup and delivery locations that will not create, or materially contribute to, a parking problem. 
(3)  Have a vehicle speed that will not create traffic congestion or safety problems. 
(4)  Utilize streets of sufficient width, including vision clearance at intersections, so that it will not materially contribute to traffic and pedestrian safety problems. 
(5)  Have a fixed route with passengers picked up only at a specified single point of origin and passengers shall be returned to that same point. 
(6)  Have to comply with applicable subsections if it involves the operation of pedicabs. In addition, the following criteria apply only to pedicabs. 
(7)  Any route used will not create traffic congestion or adversely affect the character or privacy of a residential area. 
(8)  The manner and method of pickup and delivery of passengers will not create, or materially contribute to, a parking problem or traffic congestion. 
(9)  Prior to the operation of any pedicab and at the beginning of each shift or each day of operation, the pedicab shall be thoroughly inspected by the operator and found to be in safe operating condition. An inspection for safe operating conditions must include, but is not limited to, inspection of brakes including parking brake; all lights, signals and reflectors; steering system; mirrors; horn and other warning devices; and tires. For any condition found then or at any other time that will prevent the safe operation of the pedicab, the operator shall immediately remove the pedicab from service and correct the condition before the pedicab is returned to service. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 23-5. - Factors considered. 
    Within its legislative discretion, the city council may consider the following relevant factors in making its determination: 
(1)  The adequacy of existing vehicles for hire and other forms of transportation for passengers, already in existence. 
(2)  The probable permanence and quality of the service offered by the applicant. 
(3)  The character of service proposed by the applicant as demonstrated by: the proposed communication system; the proposed use of terminals and private and public stands; the proposed service schedule; and the proposed number and type of vehicles. 
(4)  The financial status, character and responsibility of the applicant as demonstrated by: the applicant's ability to provide, maintain and operate the number of vehicles proposed to be operated in accordance with the character of service proposed in the application. 
(5)  The experience of the applicant in vehicle for hire operations as an owner or manager or as a driver. 
(6)  The degree to which the approval of an application will impact on the level of healthy competition within the city. 
(7)  The impact on public facilities likely if the new vehicles for hire are added. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 23-6. - Operations prohibited. 
    Franchise operators shall not: 
(1)  Respond to specific or individual calls for transportation from one point to another in the manner of taxicabs or otherwise perform the services of taxicabs as defined in this chapter. 
(2)  Attempt to promote patronage through garish display of colors, sounds, murals or other thematic devices located on the vehicle. 
(3)  Have to comply with applicable law if the operation involves pedicabs. 
(4)  Operate or allow the operation of any vehicle or tour bus unless the operator possesses a valid driver's license. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 23-7. - Signs. 
(a)  Any sign located on a vehicle must not exceed four square feet in area on any one side of the vehicle. For purposes of this subsection, sign means any insignia, identification, description, illustration, symbol, logo, decal or printed or graphic information. 
(b)  Upon completion and submission of a sign permit application to the community appearance board and upon payment to the city of a fee to be established by resolution of the city council, the city manager will issue to the operator of any special vehicle a special vehicle boarding zone sign permit and a special vehicle boarding zone sign. The sign is to be affixed by the operator to such post, light pole, or other location as may be specified in the permit, and only during hours the special vehicle is in operation. The sign is to be in such standardized format as the city manager may specify; of approximately the same size as a standard city parking-hours sign; and designed so as to generally resemble some type of sign sanctioned in most current edition of the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices. The sign is to read "Touring/Horse Drawn Carriage/Pedicab/{as the case may be} Boards Here." The sign will remain the property of the city and must be returned to the city engineer upon expiration of the operator's permit. The sign is deemed to be a visitor informational sign placed by the City of Myrtle Beach in the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 23-8. - Sound amplification. 
    No form of sound amplification intended to be heard outside of the special vehicle or touring bus shall be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 23-9. - Liability insurance required. 
    Prior to the issuance of a permit, the applicant shall furnish to the city a certificate of liability insurance coverage providing limits of at least $1,000,000.00 per occurrence in combined single limit for bodily injury and property damage claims or $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury and $100,000.00 per occurrence for property damage. Liability coverage shall be provided on an "occurrence" not "claims" basis. The certificate shall provide that the insurance is not cancelable without 30 days prior written notice to the city. The City of Myrtle Beach, its officers, employees, and agents shall be named as additional insureds. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Sec. 23-10. - Franchise fee. 
    Franchise fees shall be set by ordinance of the city council. If the franchise fee is granted, a regular annual business license fee shall be obtained by the franchisor prior to operation of the touring vehicle or special vehicle. No portion of the business license fee shall be refundable in the event the operation is discontinued for any reason. 
(Ord. No. 2008-49, 8-26-08) 
Secs. 23-11-23-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-21, adopted May 8, 2007, repealed the former art. II, §§ 23-21-23-46, and enacted a new art. II as set out herein. The former art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 98-21, adopted April 28, 1998. 

Sec. 23-21. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to regulate and control the operation of taxicabs for hire in the city in order to ensure an adequate and regular level of service to the public and to preserve the health and welfare of the citizens and visitors to the city and to protect their property. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-22. - Definitions. 
    Unless it appears from the context that a different meaning is intended, the following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section: 
    Association means any group of two or more certificate-holders operating taxicabs not under common ownership but under unified control, and using one common dispatch center. 
    Certificate means the certificate of public convenience and necessity authorized by the city to grant permission to operate a taxicab in the city subject to such regulations as may be enacted from time to time. 
    Certificate holder means any individual, association, partnership, company, corporation or other organization that has been granted a certificate of public convenience and necessity as provided in this chapter. 
    City means the City of Myrtle Beach, its officials, appointees, and employees. 
    City manager means the City Manager of the City of Myrtle Beach and any agents duly appointed by the city manager. 
    Driver means the person actually driving the taxicab for-hire. 
    Permit means the chauffeur's permit as described in this chapter. 
    Police chief means the Chief of Police of the City of Myrtle Beach and any agents duly appointed by the chief of police. 
    Taxicab means any motor vehicle equipped with a taximeter, top light, and proper lettering, all as required in this article, having a seating capacity of not more than fifteen passengers, including the driver, and not operating on a regular route or between terminals, used in the transportation of passengers for hire or for compensation. 
    Taxicab business means the business of transporting passengers for compensation by taxicab. 
    Taxi hearing panel or hearing panel means a five person panel appointed by the manager to receive applications for certificates and to hear appeals regarding suspension and revocation. No member of the police department can be appointed. 
    Taxicab service means and includes the operation of any taxicab upon any street or highway on call or on demand accepting or soliciting passengers indiscriminately for transportation between such points along streets or highways as may be directed by the passenger or passengers so being transported. 
    Taximeter means a mechanical instrument or device by which the charge for hire of a taxicab is mechanically calculated either for distance traveled or for waiting time, or both, and upon which such charge shall be indicated by means of figures. 
    Vehicle-owner means any person, association, partnership, corporation or other organization having title to or leasing any taxicab as herein defined. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07; Ord. No. 2012-66, 12-11-12) 
Sec. 23-23. - Certificate of public convenience and necessity. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to engage in the taxicab business unless a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall have been issued by the taxi hearing panel. 
(b)  Application for certificate. 
(1)  Application for a certificate shall be made by the prospective certificate-holder to the city manager upon forms provided by the city. Application will only be accepted in January of each year. A nonrefundable application fee will be required. The manager shall review and forward the applications to the hearing panel. 
(2)  In addition to other pertinent information that the city manager or hearing panel may require, the applicant shall provide the following: 
a.  The full name and the home and business address of the applicant and all partners or individuals with an ownership interest in the taxicab business. If the applicant is a corporation, a certified copy of the articles of incorporation and the names and the home and business addresses and home and business phone numbers of all officers and owners of the corporation along with the respective percent of ownership interest which they hold (if any). 
b.  The trade name and the telephone numbers under which the applicant does or proposes to do business. 
c.  The number of taxicabs proposed to be operated by the applicant including the year, make, model, vehicle identification number (if known at the time of application), body style, seating capacity and proposed color scheme of each vehicle. The applicant is not required to own the proposed vehicles before being authorized a certificate by city manager, but must provide all the foregoing information to the city before a certificate will be issued. 
d.  The description and location of the depots and terminals to be used, if any. 
e.  A description of the communications system to be used between dispatcher and taxicabs. 
f.  The schedule of services to be provided including the hours of the day that service will be provided and the number of months each year that service will be provided. 
g.  Each conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere for the violation of any criminal law, whether such violation be of an ordinance, state law or federal law, of the applicant and all partners or persons with an ownership interest in the taxicab business. 
h.  The specific experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers for hire. 
i.  All facts or circumstances upon which the applicant bases his belief that public convenience and necessity require the granting of his application. 
(c)  Review by city manager. The city manager shall investigate the qualifications of each applicant for a certificate and shall transmit his recommendations to the hearing panel. Prior to making a decision, the hearing panel shall review all of the information provided on the application for a certificate; cause a background investigation into the character of the applicants and the officers of the applicant; and evaluate the application using the factors contained in section 23-34. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-24. - Determination of public welfare; issuance of certificates. 
(a)  The applicant shall have the burden of establishing that the award of the certificate of public convenience and necessity will enhance the public welfare. 
(b)  The hearing panel shall determine whether the award of any certificate will enhance the public welfare after a public hearing in which testimony is heard concerning economic considerations, public need, and potential benefits to the public. This hearing shall be held within 30 days after the date of the city manager's recommendations. The hearing may be continued by motion in its sole discretion from time to time and from place to place. The hearing panel shall also consider the following relevant factors in making its determination. 
(1)  The adequacy of existing taxicab service and other forms of transportation for passengers, already in existence. 
(2)  The probable permanence and quality of the service offered by the applicant. 
(3)  The character of taxicab service proposed by the applicant as demonstrated by: the proposed communication system; the proposed use of terminals and private and public taxi stands; the proposed service schedule; and the proposed number and type of vehicles. 
(4)  The financial status, character and responsibility of the applicant as demonstrated by: the applicant's ability to provide, maintain and operate the number of vehicles proposed to be operated in accordance with the character of service proposed in the application; and the applicant's criminal and traffic record. 
(5)  The experience of the applicant in taxicab operations as an owner or manager or as a taxicab driver. 
(6)  The degree to which the approval of an application will impact on the level of healthy competition within the taxicab industry. 
(7)  The impact on public facilities likely if the new taxicabs are added. 
(c)  At the hearing before the hearing panel, the applicant shall have the right to present his case in person or by a representative of his choice. 
(d)  The hearing panel shall consider the case record as well as statements offered by any interested party. The hearing need not be conducted according to technical rules relating to evidence and witnesses. Any relevant evidence may be admitted if it is the sort of evidence on which responsible persons are accustomed to rely in the conduct of serious affairs, regardless of the existence of any common law or statutory rule that might make improper the admission of such evidence in civil actions. 
(e)  After the public hearing, the hearing panel may authorize certificates for the number of vehicles applied for, for a lesser number than that applied for, or the manager may deny issuance of any certificate. The applicant shall be notified of the decision by certified mail to the address provide on the application. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-25. - Denial of certificate; appeal. 
(a)  The hearing panel may deny an application for a certificate for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Whenever in sole judgment based on facts and circumstances, a determination has is reached that issuance of the certificate would not be in the best interest of the public or that any increase in the number of authorized taxicabs would be detrimental to the public welfare. 
(2)  Whenever an applicant has submitted incomplete or false information on an application for a certificate. 
(3)  Whenever it is determined that an applicant or any principal in the applicant's company or any officer or manager within the company: 
a.  Has been convicted or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere to the violation of any law involving a sex offense, soliciting for prostitution, or the manufacturing or distribution of any drug classified as a controlled substance; or 
b.  Has been convicted or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere to the violation of any law involving illegal drugs or controlled substances other than those offenses listed in a. above, gambling, or a crime involving moral turpitude in the five years preceding the application; or 
c.  Is on parole or probation for a criminal offense. 
(b)  A denial by the hearing panel may be appealed to city council with 15 days of denial with a delivery of a notice of appeal to the city manager. The city council shall convene for a de novo review within 30 days of receipt of the notice of appeal. The council shall have the authority to uphold, reverse or modify the decision of the hearing panel based on its interpretation of the facts and applicable sections of this article. The council shall announce its decision before the conclusion of the hearing and provide a written decision to the parties within ten days thereafter, provided however, the council's decision shall be effective immediately when the decision is announced. Proceedings before the panel and the council shall be recorded on audiotape. Either party may have the proceedings stenographically recorded at its own expense. The decision of the council shall be final. To the extent an appeal is permitted under law, an adverse decision by the city council may be appealed to the Circuit Court in and for Horry County by filing with the clerk of such court a petition in writing setting forth plainly, fully and distinctly wherein such decision is contrary to law. Such appeal shall be filed within 30 days after the decision of the council is announced. The filing of such appeal does not stay the implementation of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-26. - Certificate generally; form, term, transferability, transfer of control. 
(a)  A separate certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be issued by the city for each taxicab authorized by city manager, provided that, within 30 days of notice of managers decision to authorize the issuance of a certificate, the applicant provides the year, make, model and vehicle identification number of the vehicle to be operated subject to the certificate to the city. If the applicant fails to provide that number to the city within 30 days, the authorization shall automatically be canceled and no certificate will be issued. 
(b)  The certificate of public convenience and necessity shall state the following: 
(1)  The name and business address of the certificate-holder. 
(2)  The year, make, model, and vehicle identification number of the vehicle for which the certificate is issued. 
(3)  The date of issuance. 
(4)  The fact that the certificate is being issued subject to the provisions of this chapter and all other laws and ordinances governing the operation of public vehicles, taxicabs and for-hire vehicles in the city. 
(c)  Every certificate of public convenience and necessity issued shall be valid from the date of issuance until surrendered, revoked or suspended as provided herein, provided, however, that an annual renewal fee would be required. If any renewal fee is not received by the city on or before the renewal date a penalty of ten percent will be assessed. If the renewal fee and any penalty assessed are not received within 30 days after the renewal date, the certificate will be revoked. In order to spread the dates of renewal throughout the year, the schedule for renewal of certificates shall be as follows: 
If the taxicab number ends in: The annual renewal date shall be: 00 to 08 January 2 09 to 17 February 1 18 to 25 March 1 26 to 34 April 1 35 to 43 May 1 44 to 51 June 1 52 to 59 July 1 60 to 67 August 1 68 to 75 September 1 76 to 83 October 1 84 to 91 November 1 92 to 99 December 1  
(d)  Each certificate of public convenience and necessity will be issued to a specific individual or business entity. A certificate shall not be transferred to another individual or business entity unless such transfer is approved by the city as provided herein. A change in ownership or control of a business entity shall be considered the transfer of all certificates issued to that business entity and shall require approval by the city. If such approval is not obtained in advance of any transfer the affected certificate or certificates shall be automatically revoked. 
(1)  If the transfer of a certificate is proposed to be to an individual or business entity that has one or more valid certificates and is currently operating one or more taxicabs in full compliance with this article, the city manager may approve the transfer and issue a new certificate to the transferee. The transferee will be required to pay a fee equal to the annual renewal fee for certificates 
(2)  If the transfer of a certificate is proposed to be to an individual or business entity that does not currently hold a certificate, the transferee shall notify the city manager in writing and provide all of the information required in section 23-23(b) as if making application for a new certificate. Within 15 days of receipt, the manager shall make his recommendation to the hearing panel. Within 30 days of the manager's recommendation the hearing panel shall convene and make its determination. The fee for issuance of an original certificate will be required to be paid by the transferee. The request to approve a transfer shall then be processed for approval in the same manner as an application for an original certificate with the exception that it may be submitted and processed at any time without regard to the provision of section 23-23. 
(e)  A certificate holder may substitute a vehicle for the taxicab authorized by a certificate by surrendering the existing certificate and the taxicab decal from the old taxicab and requesting a new certificate for the vehicle to be substituted. Upon a determination by the police chief that the certificate holder is in full compliance with the provisions of this article and that the vehicle to be substituted qualifies for issuance of a taxicab decal, a new certificate and decal will be issued. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07; Ord. No. 2007-49, 7-24-07) 
Sec. 23-27. - Revocation or suspension of certificates; appeal. 
(a)  The chief of police, or his designee, may suspend certificates of public convenience and necessity for such period of time as is necessary for the correction of a violation any failure of duty or obligation arising under this chapter. 
(b)  The police chief, or his designee, shall revoke all of the certificates held by any individual or entity whenever the chief discovers reliable information which was not available to city manager when manager approved the issuance of the certificate(s), if such information would have provided grounds for denial of the application by city manager pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  The police chief, or his designee, shall revoke all of the certificates held by an individual or entity whenever the chief discovers that subsequent to the issuance of the certificate(s), events have occurred which would provide grounds to deny a future application for a permit pursuant to the provisions of section 23-25(3). 
(d)  The police chief, or his designee, shall revoke certificates in violation of section 23-41. 
(e)  A suspension or revocation of any certificate, decal, or chauffeur's permit by the chief of police or designee pursuant to the provisions of this article is effective immediately, but is subject to appeal. When the police find a violation of the provisions of this chapter, the certificate may be suspended until such time as the violation is corrected, provided however the application and fixed time limits of sections 23-29, 23-39 and 23-41 shall remain in effect, or the police chief or his designee, may revoke as provided by law. Such suspension or revocation shall be effective immediately and shall be reduced to writing, but is subject to appeal. To appeal, the certificate holder shall submit to the police chief or his designee in writing a notice of appeal, and the reason why the suspension or revocation is in error. A five-person panel, appointed by the city manager, shall conduct the scheduled hearing within 15 calendar days of the city's receipt of the notice of appeal. The city manager shall also designate one of his appointees to act as chairperson. At the hearing, the panel shall accept any relevant documents or statements from the holder and from the police chief, or his designee. The panel shall have the authority to uphold, reverse or modify the decision of the police chief or designee based on its interpretation of the facts and applicable sections of this article. The decision of the panel shall be approved by a majority of the panel members. The panel shall announce its decision before the conclusion of the hearing and provide a written decision to the parties within ten days thereafter. The panel's decision shall be effective immediately when the decision is announced. Proceedings before the panel shall be recorded on audiotape. Either party may have the proceedings stenographically recorded at its own expense. The decision of the panel shall be final. To the extent an appeal is permitted under law, an adverse decision by the hearing panel may be appealed to the Circuit Court in and for Horry County by filing with the clerk of such court a petition in writing setting forth plainly, fully and distinctly wherein such decision is contrary to law. Such appeal shall be filed within 30 days after the decision of the hearing panel is announced. The filing of such appeal does not stay the implementation of the panel's decision. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07; Ord. No. 2007-49, 7-24-07) 
Sec. 23-28. - Individual taxicab decal. 
(a)  Required. 
(1)  For each taxicab covered by certificate, a taxicab decal shall be issued in a form prescribed by the police chief. This decal is the property of the city, is not transferable, and must be returned to the city immediately when demanded by the police chief or as may be required elsewhere herein. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to operate a taxicab in the city without the decal conspicuously displayed in a manner prescribed by the police chief. 
(b)  Insurance. No taxicab decal shall be issued for the operation of a vehicle as a taxicab in the city until the vehicle owner shall have filed with the city proof of insurance, issued in the name of the certificate holder, acceptable to the city indemnifying the public against personal injury and property damage which may be caused by operation of the vehicle as a taxicab. The limits of liability shall be at least those required by state law. Insurance certificates provided to the city shall provide a minimum of 30 days written notification to the city prior to any cancellation, lapse, modification or termination of the insurance. No holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall dispatch any taxicab for which the public liability insurance has lapsed, terminated, or been modified so that it no longer complies with state law or the requirement of this article. At any time the police chief learns that the required insurance coverage for any taxicab is no longer in force, the taxicab decal shall be suspended or revoked pursuant to the provisions of section 23-27. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-29. - Chauffeur's permit. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a taxicab for hire in the city to pick up any passenger for transport to any destination either within or outside the city unless he or she shall have obtained a city chauffeur's permit in addition to any motor vehicle operators licenses required by the state. 
(b)  Application for permit. 
(1)  Application for the permit shall be made in person to the agent of agents prescribed by the city. 
(2)  Application for a permit shall be made upon forms provided by the city. The applicant shall provide information regarding the following: 
a.  Pertinent personal data. 
b.  Traffic record (excluding parking citations) for ten years previous to the date of the application. 
c.  Criminal record. 
d.  Prior driving experience. 
(3)  The applicant shall permit the city to make a record of his/her fingerprints. 
(4)  When an application has been denied, the applicant may not reapply for a permit for 30 days from the date of denial. 
(c)  Investigation of applicant. The police chief shall have an investigation made of the facts stated in an application for a permit and other relevant data. Except for information, which, by law, may not be released, the file shall be available to the applicant or his agent upon written authorization of the applicant. 
(d)  Issuance of permit. 
(1)  If the police chief finds that the applicant is duly qualified, and of good moral character, he shall issue a taxicab driver's permit to the applicant. 
(2)  The police chief may refuse to issue a permit to an applicant for any of the following reasons: 
a.  From any state within the last two years of application, a conviction, bond forfeiture or pleas of a DUI, DWI or similar intoxicated driving offense as recognized by another state; passing a stopped school bus, hit and run property damage, or a reckless driving or similar driving offense as recognized by another state; within South Carolina, an accumulation of eight points within the past 18 months, based upon the following State of South Carolina assessment: 
Reckless driving: Six. 
Passing stopped school bus: Six. 
Hit-and-run, property damages only: Six. 
Driving too fast for conditions, or speeding: 
1.  No more than ten m.p.h. above the posted limits: Two. 
2.  More than ten m.p.h. but less than 25 m.p.h. above the posted limits: Four. 
3.  Twenty-five m.p.h. or above the posted limits: Six. 
Disobedience of any official traffic control device: Four. 
Disobedience to officer directing traffic: Four. 
Failing to yield right-of-way: Four. 
Driving on wrong side of road: Four. 
Passing unlawfully: Four. 
Turning unlawfully: Four. 
Driving through or within safety zone: Four. 
Failing to give signal or giving improper signal for stopping, turning, or suddenly decreased speed: Four. 
Shifting lanes without safety precaution: Two. 
Improper dangerous parking: Two. 
Following too closely: Four. 
Failing to dim lights: Two. 
Operating with improper lights: Two. 
Operating with improper brakes: Four. 
Operating a vehicle in unsafe condition: Two. 
Driving in improper lane: Two. 
Improper backing: Two. 
b.  Conviction, plea of guilty or plea of nolo contendere to the violation of any law involving any sex offense; soliciting for prostitution; or the manufacturing or distribution of any drug classified as a controlled substance. 
c.  Conviction, plea of guilty, or plea of nolo contendere to any felony; the violation of any law involving illegal drugs or controlled substances other than those offenses listed in b. above; gambling; or a crime of moral turpitude in the ten years preceding the application. 
d.  If applicant is on parole or probation for a criminal or traffic offense. 
(3)  No permit shall be issued to any person: 
a.  Who has less than six months driving experience. 
b.  Who is not appropriately licensed to legally operate a motor vehicle in the state. In this regard all South Carolina residents will be required to have a valid South Carolina license before a permit will be issued. 
c.  Who is less than 21 years of age. 
(4)  Upon initial review of the application, and after performing the records checks which are available to the police department on a real-time basis, the police chief may issue a temporary permit which authorizes the driver to operate a taxicab for an interim period not to exceed 30 days while the applicant obtains all other required records. 
(e)  Permits generally; form, term, renewal, transferability. 
(1)  Form. The form of the permit shall be prescribed by the police chief with the proviso that the permit shall bear a recent photograph of the license holder. 
(2)  Term. Original permit shall be valid for one year from date of issuance. Permits may be renewed for a two-year period provided that the police chief's investigation of the driver's traffic and criminal record reveals no criminal or traffic violation during the period of his expiring permit. If the investigation reveals such violations, the permit may be renewed for one year only. 
(3)  Transferability. The permit is the property of the city and is not transferable to any other driver and it shall be surrendered to the police chief by the driver upon such driver's ceasing to drive a taxicab in the city. 
(4)  Display required. It shall be unlawful to operate a taxicab without the driver's permit being conspicuously displayed in a manner prescribed by the police chief. 
(f)  Renewal of permit. An application for a renewal of a permit shall conform to the procedures set forth in section 23-29(b), except that traffic records need only be reported for the period since the latest permit issuance. 
(g)  Surrender, suspension and revocation of permit. 
(1)  The police chief may suspend the permit of any person licensed under this article for any of the following: 
a.  Applicability of 23-29(d)(2)(a) for 60 days. 
b.  Conviction of reckless driving for 90 days. 
c.  Failure to report any accident in which the operator is involved, however slight for 90 days. 
d.  Driving of any taxicab known to the driver not to be in good order and repair for 30 days. 
e.  Two or more violations of section 23-36 of this Code in a calendar for 30 days. 
f.  For knowingly making a false statement of material and relevant facts on an application for a taxicab driver's permit 365 days. 
(2)  Upon a determination by the police chief that a second violation of any of the conditions contained in (1) above has occurred within 18 months of the date of first offence, the chief shall revoke the driver's permit. 
(3)  The taxicab driver's permit of any operator shall automatically be revoked and shall be immediately surrendered by him upon his conviction of or plea of guilty or nolo contenders to any violation involving: 
a.  Commission of a felony. 
b.  Any sex offense. 
c.  Soliciting for prostitution. 
d.  Any drug classified as a controlled substance. 
e.  Revocation of permits to drive. 
(4)  A driver whose permit has been revoked shall be notified by certified mail and may not reapply for a license for one year from the date of revocation; provided, however, that if the revocation was because of revocation of permits to drive issued by the state, the driver may reapply when all required state driving permits have been reacquired. Appeal shall be as found in section 23-27(d). 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07; Ord. No. 2007-49, 7-24-07) 
Sec. 23-30. - Fees generally. 
    The following fees shall be paid when applicable: 
(1)  For each original application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity the fee shall be $500.00, which shall be refunded should the city council deny issuance of the certificate. An additional fee of $500.00 per VIN number will be required at the time each certificate is issued. 
(2)  For the annual renewal of a certificate the fee shall be $300.00. When renewals are required on other than a 12-month basis, the fee shall be equal to $25.00 times the number of full months or parts thereof which have passed since the original issuance of the certificate or the most recent renewal. 
(3)  For the replacement of a lost, stolen, damaged, or destroyed certificate the fee shall be $50.00. 
(4)  For each original application, renewal or replacement of a chauffeur's permit the fee shall be $50.00. 
(5)  For each taxicab decal, or each substitution procedure provided for in section 26-23(e) the fee shall be $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07; Ord. No. 2008-48, § 1, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 23-31. - Records required. 
(a)  Information to be provided to police department by certificate-holders. Every certificate-holder shall maintain on file with an agent designated by the police chief his name, his company's name, business address, garage address, all business telephone numbers listed in his and his company's name and names of all drivers, their license numbers and addresses, the names and addresses of all vehicle owners, the make and meter number of taximeters in each vehicle, and shall, within 48 hours after any change in connection therewith, report such change. 
(b)  Drivers daily manifest. Every driver shall maintain a daily manifest upon which are recorded: The time the taxicab began operation and stopped operation on the street, the taxicab number and driver's name, all trips made each day showing time and place of origin and destination of each trip, the number of passengers and amount of fare. This information shall be recorded at the end of each trip. In addition, the driver shall record on each manifest the meter register readings at the beginning and end of each tour of duty for total miles, paid miles, trips, units, extra passengers, as well as the odometer readings. All such completed manifests shall be returned to the certificate-holder by the driver at the conclusion of his tour of duty. If the driver changes taxicabs during his tour of duty he shall maintain a separate manifest for that portion of the tour of duty in which another vehicle is used. The forms for such records shall be furnished to the driver by the certificate-holder and shall be subject to the approval of the police chief. It shall be unlawful to maintain an incomplete manifest. Every certificate-holder shall retain and preserve all drivers' manifests in a safe place for at least 36 months and the same shall be made available upon demand for inspection by an agent of the police chief. 
(c)  Lost articles. Any article found in a taxicab shall be noted on the driver's manifest and be delivered immediately to the police department unless it can be returned to its rightful owner. 
(d)  Accident reports. As required by section 23-37. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-32. - Taximeters. 
(a)  Charges by taximeter. No person owning, operating or controlling any taxicab upon the streets of the city shall charge for the use of such taxicab to exceed the current rates to be determined by the taximeter. These rates shall be set from time to time by the city manager and a schedule of such fees is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  Taximeter required; definition; specifications. Every taxicab shall have affixed thereto and must use a taximeter of a size and design approved by the police department and conform substantially to the following specifications: 
(1)  A taximeter is a mechanical instrument or device by which the charge for hire of a taxicab is mechanically calculated either for distance traveled or for waiting time or both and upon which such charge shall be indicated by means of legible figures which are electrically lighted each time the taximeter flag is thrown from nonearning to earning position. 
(2)  Such taximeters must register upon visual counters the following items: 
a.  Total miles; 
b.  Paid miles; 
(3)  Each taximeter must have a "dead-clock." 
(c)  Taximeter flag. The taximeter flag shall not be changed to vacant position until the fare is paid. 
(d)  Inspection and sealing required; retesting upon change from one taxicab to another. No person shall drive a taxicab to which is attached a taximeter that has not been inspected and approved by the police department. The pinion gear shall be sealed so that it cannot be removed or changed without breaking or otherwise damaging the seal. It shall be unlawful to change the gears operating the taximeter, remove the gear seal, or change a taximeter from one taxicab to another unless the taximeter is inspected, retested, and approved by the police department, prior to use. 
(e)  Unlawful to operate without. It shall be unlawful for any taxicab to be operated for public hire unless it is equipped with a taximeter which must be used as provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-33. - Taxicab stands. 
    The city manager may designate taxicab stands on the public right-of-way at which taxicabs may park and from which they may solicit fares in the city. Such stands so designated, and none other on the public right-of-way, may be used for parking and soliciting fares. The police department shall supervise and regulate such stands. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-34. - Display of fares. 
    The prices which will be charged for carrying passengers and baggage in a taxicab shall be prominently displayed in each taxicab in a location clearly visible to the passengers. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-34.1. - Fares. 
    The schedule of maximum rates to be charged for the use of any taxicab within the city shall read as follows: 
(1)  For the first one-eighth mile ..... $1.50 
(2)  For each additional one-eighth mile ..... 0.35 
(3)  For each 55 seconds of waiting ..... 0.35 
(4)  Passengers in excess of one person per trip above the age of 15 ..... 1.00 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07; Ord. No. 2008-48, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 23-35. - Disputes. 
    All disputes as to fares shall be resolved by the police department within 24 hours at the police department and both passenger and driver shall comply with such resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-36. - Conduct. 
    No driver of a taxicab shall: 
(1)  Permit more persons to ride in the front seat of any taxicab than the number of seat belts installed in the front seat. 
(2)  Deceive or attempt to deceive any passenger who may ride in his taxicab, or who may desire to ride in such taxicab, as to his destination or the rate of fare to be charged or shall convey any passenger or cause him to be conveyed to a place other than directed by him, and in no event shall any operator take a longer route to the destination than necessary unless so requested by the passenger or passengers. 
(3)  Fail to comply with all reasonable and lawful requests of the passenger or passengers as to the speed of travel and the route to be taken. 
(4)  Have in his possession a lighted cigarette, cigar or pipe while any passenger is being carried therein. 
(5)  Solicit passengers while taxicab is standing or in motion on any public street or other location, provided that nothing herein shall be held to prohibit a driver from alighting to the street or sidewalk for the purpose of assisting passengers into or out of the taxicab. 
(6)  Solicit passengers by any sign or in any manner annoy any person or obstruct the movement of any person, or follow any person for the purpose of soliciting patronage. 
(7)  Receive or discharge passengers in the roadway but shall pull up to the right-hand sidewalk, or in the absence of a sidewalk, to the extreme right-hand side of the road and there receive or discharge passengers. 
(8)  Cruise in search of passengers at any time. 
(9)  Solicit patronage of persons assembled at the terminal of any other common carrier, nor at any intermediate points along any established route of such carrier, when such persons have assembled for the purpose of using the service of the common carrier. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to prohibit or interfere with response to any call for a taxicab made by signal from a pedestrian. 
(10)  Permit more persons to be carried in a taxicab in the city at any one time than the seating capacity of the taxicab, including the driver, children in arms exempted. 
(11)  Refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person upon request, unless previously engaged or unable or forbidden by the provisions of this article to do so. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-37. - Engaging cab with fraudulent intent. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to engage or use any taxicab not intending at the time when such taxicab is engaged to pay the legal fare with the intent to defraud the owner or driver of such taxicab of such fare. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-38. - Reporting accidents. 
    All traffic accidents involving any taxicab covered by this chapter resulting in any damage or injury to any person, real property or personal property, no matter how slight, and regardless of whether it is investigated by a police agency or not, must be reported to the police department in writing by the certificate holder within 24 hours from the time of occurrence. This report shall provide the name of the driver, his taxi permit number, complete vehicle registration information on the taxicab involved, as well as the taxi number. It will also include the date, time and location of the accident and a brief summary of the details of the accident. Damage to the taxicab will be listed on the report. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-39. - Repair of damage; time limit. 
    Any dents, nicks, scratches, or other damage resulting from a traffic accident which does not require that the taxicab be removed immediately from service for repairs will be repaired within, but no later than, 45 days from the date of the accident or the vehicle's taxicab decal will be removed and the vehicle removed from service until such time as the damage has been repaired. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-40. - Equipment; appearance, construction and maintenance. 
(a)  [Requirements.] In addition to equipment required of motor vehicles by the Code of Laws of South Carolina (1976), as amended, every taxicab certified under this chapter: 
(1)  Shall be equipped with a frame or holder for the proper display of the chauffeur's permit, which shall face the passengers and be so located as to be at all times in plain view of such passengers. The card frame or holder and the manner and location where it is mounted shall be subject to approval of the police chief. 
(2)  Shall be equipped with a heater and air conditioner sufficient to heat and cool the interior of the taxicab adequately. 
(3)  Shall not be equipped with shades or curtains which can be manipulated in such a way as to shield the occupants or the driver from observation or obstruct the driver's view using the rear-view mirror. No windows in the taxicab shall be tinted to the extent that the driver and all passengers cannot be easily seen from outside the taxicab. 
(4)  Shall be a motor vehicle designed and manufactured to have a seating capacity of not more than fifteen passengers (including the driver). 
(5)  Shall be equipped with approved safety non-shatterable glass in the windshield and all windows. The center partition if any, between the driver's compartment and the passenger compartment shall be of this type glass or plastic. 
(6)  Shall be equipped with a standard speedometer properly installed, maintained in good working order and exposed to view. No taxicab shall be operated in taxicab service while such speedometer is out of repair or disconnected. 
(7)  Shall not be equipped with any other lights or signal device except as allowed by the Code of Laws of South Carolina (1976), as amended, or approved by the police chief. 
(8)  Shall be equipped with a taximeter as prescribed by this chapter. 
(9)  Shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be swept and dusted at least once each day that it is in service. At least once every seven days the exterior shall be washed and the interior shall be cleansed thoroughly. 
(10)  With the exception of a "kick" strip not exceeding seven inches in height at the bottom of doors, no upholstery covering or interior lining below the windows shall be permitted in any taxicab unless it shall be of leather or similar non-absorbent, washable material. The rear cushion shall be removable. No floor covering or mat shall be permitted in any licensed taxicab unless it shall be made of rubber, leather or metal chain, or a similar nonabsorbent, washable material, provided, however, that if absorbent floor covering is installed as original equipment in the taxicab, it may be retained but must be fully covered with nonabsorbent, removable and washable mats. Variations of this provision will be permitted where strict compliance is impossible because of scarcity of materials. 
(11)  Every taxicab shall be of good substantial appearance and be so constructed and maintained as to provide for the safety of the public, continuous and satisfactory operation, and operation at minimum noise and vibration. Every taxicab shall be structurally sound as to all its parts, shall not have broken or cracked fenders or glass, and shall be painted to give reasonable protection to all painted surfaces from structural deterioration. All marks of identification on taxicabs shall be permanent and clearly legible at all times. 
(12)  Reserved. 
(13)  Reserved. 
(14)  After April 28, 2000, shall not have any sign, lettering, or message affixed or attached in any way except as required or authorized in subsection (b) herein. 
(b)  Color scheme and required lettering on taxicab. 
(1)  All certificate holders shall adopt a separate color scheme for painting their taxicabs which is distinct from that of any other certificate holder. All taxicabs of each certificate holder shall be of the same color scheme; provided, however, that an association including two or more certificate holders shall adopt one uniform color scheme for all taxicabs operated under the control of the association. 
(2)  The name of the certificate holder or association, taxicab number and telephone number shall be displayed with permanent lettering on both sides and rear of each cab with letters and numbers at least four inches high. 
(3)  Lettering or numbers shall not be acceptable which are on a sheet of metal or other material which in turn can be removed or detached. 
(4)  If a taxicab is owned by a person other than the business entity whose name appears on the taxicab, the name of the owner shall be painted in permanent lettering on both sides of the taxicab in letters one and one-half inches high and located below the name of the entity. 
(5)  The taxicab numbers on the side and rear of each taxicab will be assigned at the time the certificate for the taxicab is issued, will be recorded on the certificate, and will be affixed to the taxicab by the city's inspector. No two taxicabs authorized to operate within the city shall have the same taxicab number. The number of the taxicab operated pursuant to a certificate shall not be changed unless a new certificate is issued. 
(6)  Adhesive stickers or vinyl clings showing methods of payment, American flags or the message "Thank you for Visiting", are permitted as long as the massing or placement of stickers or vinyl clings shall not act a visual barrier. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07; Ord. No. 2011-34, 6-28-11; Ord. No. 2012-66, 12-11-12) 
Sec. 23-41. - Inspection of taxicabs; procedure when taxicab is found in unsafe, unfit or unclean condition. 
    Each taxicab for which a certificate has been issued shall be inspected by an agent prescribed by the police department at least once each calendar year. In addition to the annual inspections, the police department shall each year randomly select and inspect without notice no less than 20 percent of the taxicabs for which decals have been issued. 
(1)  Unsafe vehicles. If any taxicab is found to be in unsafe condition, the taxicab decal shall be immediately removed from the vehicle and the certificate-holder shall be notified of the nature of the defect and that the taxicab shall not be operated until such condition has been remedied. The certificate holder shall be provided 30 days to have the unsafe condition corrected or to substitute another acceptable vehicle for the vehicle which was found to be unsafe. If the certificate holder fails to correct the unsafe condition or to substitute a vehicle which passes inspection within the 30-day period, the certificate shall be revoked. 
(2)  Unclean or unfit taxicabs. If the taxicab is found to be unclean or unfit, but otherwise in safe condition, the agent shall give the taxicab owner and driver a reasonable time, not to exceed 72 hours, to remedy the condition, after which the agent shall reinspect the taxicab. If the vehicle does not pass the reinspection, the decal shall be removed and the taxicab shall not be used as a taxicab until all unsatisfactory conditions have been corrected. If the vehicle does not pass inspection within 30 days from the date of the original unsatisfactory inspection, the certificate shall be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-42. - Business license required. 
    Nothing contained in the chapter shall be construed to eliminate or replace the requirement that any person doing business in the city must obtain a business license. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-43. - Reserved. 
Sec. 23-44. - Violations. 
    The violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable in accordance with section 1-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-45. - Reserved. 
    Inasmuch as taxi service is based upon public convenience and necessity, when a call for service has been made by a person on a private property, it shall be unlawful for any person or agent or employee of a business to deny entry or access to a property where other public transportation vehicle or vehicles for hire are invited to enter, or to require or demand a fee from a taxicab operator to pick up or discharge passengers at their place of business. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Sec. 23-46. - Implementation. 
    All certificates issued on or before the effective date of this article shall become void on July 1, 1998. Immediately following the effective date of this ordinance, all certificate holders will be given written notice to surrender their existing certificates to the police chief, have each taxicab inspected, and obtain a new certificate for each taxicab which was authorized under the existing certificates. In order to obtain the new certificates the holders will be required to present each vehicle at the police department for inspection. The police chief will notify the certificate holder of the time and place that the inspection will be performed. A fee equal to one half the annual renewal fee for certificates will be required to be paid at the time of inspection. If the certificate holder fails to present a vehicle for inspection and pay the required fee as scheduled, or to obtain prior approval of the police chief for an alternate schedule, no new certificate will be issued for the vehicle in question. To pass inspection, the vehicle must be in proper operating condition and meet all requirements for the issuance of a taxicab decal. The police inspector will record the year, make, model, and vehicle identification number from each vehicle and issue a new certificate for each qualified vehicle not to exceed the number of vehicles authorized on the old certificate. No certificates will be issued for taxicabs that are not presented as scheduled and approved before July 1, 1998. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, 5-8-07) 
Secs. 23-47-23-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIMOUSINES 

Sec. 23-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words or phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings as set out in this section unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    Limousine means any vehicle having a seating capacity of not more than 15 passengers including a chauffeur and used to transport passengers for compensation, but not including any vehicle operated as a taxicab as defined and regulated in article II of this chapter or any vehicle for hire which is operated or required to be operated pursuant to a franchise authorized by city council or which is operated pursuant to a class A or class B motor vehicle carrier certificate issued by the state public service commission or medical transports. 
    Limousine business means the business of transporting passengers for compensation by limousine. 
(Ord. No. 97-71, 10-28-97; Ord. No. 2012-66, 12-11-12) 
Sec. 23-51. - License required. 
    No person shall operate a limousine business within the city unless he or she has a valid current business license issued by the city business license inspector. 
(Ord. No. 97-71, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 23-52. - Chauffeur's permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating a limousine in the city to carry any passenger for any form of compensation unless he or she shall have a current city chauffeur's permit in addition to any motor vehicle operator's license required by the state. The current city chauffeur's permit shall be prominently displayed in the limousine at all times when passengers are being transported for compensation. The application for, issuance, denial, suspension and revocation of chauffeur's permits shall be governed by the applicable provisions of article II of this chapter which govern the issuance of taxi driver's permits. 
(Ord. No. 97-71, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 23-53. - Limousine decal. 
    Any person operating a limousine business shall purchase one limousine decal from the city for each vehicle to be operated as a limousine in the city. The cost of each decal shall be $5.00. Such decal shall be issued by the city business license inspector and shall expire each year on May 31. It shall be unlawful to operate a limousine in the city unless a current limousine decal purchased from the city is displayed on the lower right side of the front windshield of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 97-71, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 23-54. - Solicitation of passengers. 
(a)  No person shall solicit passengers for a limousine by cruising the streets. 
(b)  No person shall operate a limousine on the streets of the city or park anywhere within the city where it can be seen from a public right-of-way, bearing any sign or message proclaiming availability, or that the limousine is for hire or stating the price for hiring the limousine. 
(c)  No person shall park a limousine on any public property in anticipation of a call for service or without a current contract for hire or call for service. 
(d)  No person shall operate a limousine in a regulated taxi stand or taxi line without having been summoned to the location by a specifically identified customer who is waiting for service. 
(e)  No person shall operate a limousine bearing any marking other than that required by the Public Service Commission, and such shall not exceed three inches in height. No marking shall solicit business by way of sign, lettering, message, text, graphic, markings, phone numbers or addresses. 
(Ord. No. 97-71, 10-28-97; Ord. No. 2012-66, 12-11-12) 
Sec. 23-55. - Records required. 
    Each limousine business shall maintain a daily manifest record on which shall be recorded the time and place of origin, destination of each trip, all stops during the trip at which passengers entered or exited the limousine, and the driver's identity. All such records shall be maintained by the operator of the limousine business for a period of four years and made available to the chief of police or his designee for inspection and copying on request. 
(Ord. No. 97-71, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 23-56. - Fares. 
    Limousine fares shall be agreed to by the passenger or passengers prior to entering the limousine. Unless the fare agreement is in writing and signed by the passenger or is collected prior to commencement of service, it will be presumed that no agreement was reached as required herein. 
(Ord. No. 97-71, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 23-57. - Exception. 
    Nothing in this article shall apply to the operation of a limousine by a business exclusively to provide transportation for clients or customers to and from that business' place(s) of business and which is not otherwise for hire, specifically including the operating of a limousine in connection with a funeral. 
(Ord. No. 97-71, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 23-58. - Prohibitions specific to limousines. 
(a)  No person shall operate a limousine in the same manner as a taxicab by responding to a call or demand for a taxicab. 
(b)  No person shall dispatch a limousine to a call or demand for a taxicab. 
(c)  No person shall respond to a call or demand for a taxicab in a limousine. 
(Ord. No. 2012-66, 12-11-12) 
Secs. 23-59-23-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - WRECKER SERVICES; NONCONSENSUAL TOWING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Business license requirements, § 11-21 et seq.; Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12. 

DIVISION 1. - WRECKER SERVICES 

Sec. 23-125. - Definitions applicable for article VI. 
    The following words or phrases, as used in this article, shall have the following respective meanings as set out in this section, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    Advertise(s) or advertisement shall mean any representation made in connection with the solicitation of a wrecker service company and includes without limitation, those made in or through any newspaper, telephone directory, publication, radio, television, electronic medium, notice, handbill, business card, sign, catalog, billboard, brochure, poster or letter, or upon any application or form required to be submitted under law or contract. 
    Consensual towing means a tow authorized by the vehicle owner, authorized operator or authorized agent of the owner. 
    Coupling or coupled means the initial physical connection made between the wrecker vehicle and vehicle to be towed by means of moving jack, dolly, skate, strap, chain, line, bar or some other form of couplings; or with at least one half of the wheel lift apparatus surrounding a tire, of the winch hook being properly hooked to the vehicle in an appropriate place on the vehicle so that the vehicle can be safely towed or winched. Coupling does not include the positioning of the wrecker to begin the act of coupling the vehicles, commonly known as "blocking". 
    Decoupling fee means a charge by a towing company for releasing a motor vehicle to its owner or operator when the vehicle has been coupled by a wrecker, but has not completely removed the vehicle from private property. 
    Legal repossession means the act of a creditor or his duly authorized agent under contract to take possession of a vehicle under a security agreement by a lienholder; and may be referred to as an automobile recovery action, and constitutes a nonconsensual tow. 
    Normal business hours means: 
(1)  For those businesses that engage in a nonconsensual towing operation, those hours during which nonconsensual towing is available as declared by the towing service in either advertisement or in its licensing application, and excepting the act of legal repossession, their normal business hours will include the time of one hour time period that immediately begins when the wrecker operator notifies the police department that a nonconsensual tow has been accomplished, pursuant to S.C. Code, § 56-5-2525.
